CONTENTION OVER COREA. Czar and Mikado Covet the Hermit Nation. r.oth Russia and Japan want Corea, with such determination that the war clouds arc growing blanker and blacker over the Hermit Kingdom. Ti Muscovite regards the Corean peninsula es Indispensable for several reasons. Corea bears much the same relation to Asiatic Russia as did Florida to the United States In the early yearn of the last century. Russia needs these ninety thousand square miles to complete her coast lino, tor if Oorea falls under Japan's rul Russian hi a will be unable to sail through the Corean Strait without running the gantlet of Japanese eanm n on either side. Russia also wants Corea in order to have an A port which Is not ice-locked in winter. t.rt Arthur and Dalny. in spite of the Musco vite millions spent in wharf construction, have proved failures as winter harbors. Within their huge breakwaters the waters have frozen, so as jo preveat Russian ships In midwinter from reaching the piers of the Russian railroad. In Corea there are several ports which Russia would fata have as outlets to her vast Inland empire. On the western coast there is Yongam bo, near the northern boundary, and a few piles from the mouth of the Yalu Rler. Here lhe Russians have leased a large tract of terri tory, and are now building forts, although they caid primarily they only wanted the land for cutting timber. The activity at the Czar's sub jects in the neighborhood of Yonganipho has Mftedally alarmed Japan. Yoiigampho, however. Is too far north to be open In winter It to in a higher latitude than THE COMMUTER'S HOMECOMING IN WINTEIU A trifle lato for Uni.cr and a lot of mncrr,- to BhoveL PaTny or Port Artlmr. which are situated at the n3 of the neighboring Llo Tung peninsula on the western ride of Coma I Jay but in the Corean port of Chemulpo, the Russians see an opportu nity of getting an all-year-round harbor. Che mulpo is to Seoul, the capital of Corea, what the harbor of Piraeus was to classic Athens. A railroad Joins Chemulpo and Seoul, and It Is through this port that the capital city carries on Its trade with China. A third port, and the most Important of all, is Fusan, on the Bouth r-.-it-tf-rii extremity of the peninsula, which la the southern terminal of the Pusan-Beoul Railroad, Fusan might be made a powerful naval station to control the straits between Corea and Japan. At th present time the Japanese government exercises a sort if commercial protectorate over this port and one of Russia's latest moves is to get the harbor Masnmpho, which is near l'usan. Port Lazaref, on the eastern shore of Oorea, crashed by that branch of the warm Japan cur rent which enters the Corean Strait, is still an- Oth r harbor which would permit Russia to have communication with the sea. summer and winter. NEW-YORK TRIBUNE ILLUSTRATED SUPPLEMENT. THE COMMUTER'S HOME EN BUMMER. Shads trees, flowers, grassy lawns, room tar the children to romp ta without plajrlng hi Qm street I SUMMER AND WINTER IN THE SUBURBS. The Commuter Talks More About the Former tJuin He Does About the Latter Some Reasons. When the city man becomes discontented with his so many rooms and bath. and longs for the country, he should never take a suburbanite into his confidence. He will never obtain an un biassed opinion of country life by talking with a country resi lent. In the summer time he will find him full of boasts and In the winter full of explanations. The only way to get a genu ine, aboveboard, straightforward, unprejudiced conception of country life Is to visit a. suburban friend unexpectedly and see for one's self. Such a visit would better be made in the dead of winter than in midsummer. The commuter's statements regarding the beauties of nature In June and July contain a certain amount of truth that do not need Investigation by a de tective. Everybody knows that trees and grass grow in summer, and that they are pleasant to look upon. And yet the commuter always talks as if he were the first to discover that the country la pleasanter than the city in hot weather. When he eomel In from his rural home on a sultry morning and a.sks you how you slept la.st niht, you know, of course, that he slept all right him s.-lf. and that he only wants tlur c ortunity to say so. And wh-n ho gels the chance, lie will tell you how cool the nights ure at Slumber Corners, urid how the wind always circulates through that wonderful house of his, and how delightful Is the chirping of the crlcketa at night, and how healthful his cUMren are, how much they weigh, how much they eat, how much they look like him. and all because they can live iv the country. NO STEAM HEATED FLAT FOR HIM. the mtarbaa swnei contempt for city life often erta a Jar m winter, when the servant goes m strike, and ho has to tend Uxe furoa.ee and empty the ashes himself. When all other themes are exhausted, the suburbanite Is always ready to dilate on air. This subject of air Is especially dear to him, and offers a boundless field for his Intellect to dis port itself. He will tell you. to begin with, how much purer the air is in Slumber Corners than in New- York. Then again, Slumber Corners Is lio feet higher than New-York, a fact which proves that the air of Slumber Corners is dryer than that of New-York, and especially benefi cial for throat and lungs. Give him a change and he will tell how he once suffered from asth ma, catarrh, bronchitis, tonsUltls, laryngitis, with a threat of tuberculosis, before he left New-York for Slumber Corners. And should you suggest that his Manhattan ofhe, on the twentieth floor. Is even higher than the beauti ful hamlet wh-re he lives, he will tell you that New- York air is full of germs. In Slumber Cor ners germs cannot exist, although he may not say that Slumber Corners is too slow for gorms. If anything Is ev.-r said about the long ride on the ferry or the train the suburbanite Is ready with statistics to provt how rapidly he travels 1..i0k and forth each day. He has flg ored it all out to the fraction of a minute. If ho can shave an hour tewa one or two minutes he docs to. much as the storekeeper marks down his goods so as to remove the dollar sign. He telLs you it is only a six minute walk from his house to the station, that the train la an express. naJOttsj no stops, that it comes the nineteen rnlles between Slumber Corners and lioboken In thirty-five minutes, and that the terry makes the river trip tn fourteen inlut.a. The walk np from the station to the office takes only four minutes. And bo he figures that be mak s the entire journey in fifty-nine minute and adds, exultantly It's so much more convenient than The Bronx, where we once lived. Then it took me a wh.le hour. And should some Manhattanite ask him if the mosquitoes ever bother him. he always answers that Slumber Cornt-rs is wonderfully exempt from such a st, and that although all the rest of the State of New- Jersey may swarm with mosquitoes, they have never entered the Kden where he has his home. The screens in hi windows and doors and around his porch, he ex plains, are only to keep out Hies. With the coming of winter, however, the com muter grows less boastful. He is not so rady to exploit the remarkable virtues of Slumber Corners as formerly. When he comes into the office with his rubbers covered with mud, his overcoat wrinkled as if he had slept in it over night, and a thin veil of ashes on bis hat. he never calls anybody's attention to these details. And when a snowstorm sweeps down on the country and the river thickens with ice, and he gets down to the office two hours' late, he merely answers inquiries by saying that he missed the train, or that there was a change La the schedule, or that the baby wasn't well, and he wanted to have talk with the doctor. Should the city mxm. however, make his coun try friend an early and sudden visit some winter morning. h might learn that the baby's illness or a change in the timetable was by no means the sole cause of the commuter's tardiness. Could he obtain the whole truth, he would dis cover that there are certain cold, stern realities about country life In the winter that his subur ban friend had never hinted at. For example, go a ng made dark by a snowstorm the commuter generally oversleeps. When the alarm clock gos off. he opens his eyes for a moment, sees how dark it Is, and then makes himself believe the clock was set two hours to early. The snow Is coming down so quietly and the ground is so thickly carpeted that pass- Ing teams do not arouse him. It Is not until one of the children, falls out of bed or the cook drops a tray of dishes on the kitchen floor that he begins to realize that the night has passed. On such a morning the furnace fire always goes out It has kept up a heroic fight all night for its existence, but the battle was too protracted and reinforcements came too late. He tries ta wash bis face, but finds that the pipes are frozen. He looks for a clean towel, but all the towels that are not soiled were washed yester day and now hang like so many sheets of metal on the line In the back yard. Should there be no cook, the commuter crawls downstairs and builds the fire himself. He ts compelled to do this, whether he wants to or not. It is only an hour before train time, and he knows that his wife will certainly need another half hour to curl her hair before she would even be prepared to build a fire. The ashes this morning choke the range as If they had I -a accumulating for week.-, and the wood sputter and refuses to burn, Of course the wood ai left outdoors all night. After the fires are built, the commuter realize that he must clear path to the street anil clean the sidewalk. If he doesn't, he will cause trouble not only at home, but throughout Slum ber Corners. His wife will certainly catch a cold, which she will attribute to the soft snow she had to wade through and which he did not shovel away. And all the citizens who pass Ills gate will look at that uncleaned path, and sizo up the situation in one of two ways. They CuuUuuiml ou UiLrUxuitli ,1..,

It can be stated with authority that the administration does not con template paying one dollar out of the United States Treasury to Colombia on account of the secession of Panama. Nor will It go before the Hague tribunal as a party to any proceedings growing out of that secession. It Is said that to do either of these things would be to commit the administration to an admission that It had been guilty of wronging Colombia. On the other hand, it is again announced that the United States stands ready to do everything In its power to bring about an amicable under standing between Colombia and Panama. It may be that Panama will consent to go before the Hapue tribunal with Colombia and allow that tribunal to decide whether 'or not Panama shall make any concessions to Colombia on ac count of the severance of political ties. It Is certain that tne United States government would look with favor on the assumption by Panama of some small liability, to make good the heavy loss which Colombia has suffered. Reaiynbtr the bull Name Laxative Bromo Quinne -w SECURING THE OPEN DOOR CHINESE TREATY A FACT. Ratifications Exchanged and Presi dent's Proclamation Issued. Washington. Jan. 13. Ratifications of the com mercial treaty between the United States and China were exchanged at the State Department to-day by Secretary Hay and Sir Chentung Liang-Cheng, the Chinese Minister here, and lata this afternoon President Roossveit issued the following proclamation, putting the treaty Into effect By the President of the United States of Amer ica. A Proclamation Whereas, A treaty and three annexes be tween Urn United States of America and China to extend further the commercial relations be tween them and otherwise to promote the in terests of the people of the two countries were concluded and signed at Shanghai, In the Eng lish and Chinese languages, on the Bth day of October, 1900, the original of the English text of which treaty and annexes la, word for word, as follows Here is published the text of the- treaty. And whereas, The said treaty and annexes had been duly ratified on both parts, and the ratifications cf the two governments were ex changed In the dry of Washington, on the 13th day of January, 1004 Now, therefore, be it known that I, Theodore Roosevelt, President of the United States of America, have caused the said treaty and an nexes to be made public, to the end that the same and every article and clause thereof may be observed and fulfilled with good faith by the United States and the citizens thereof. In testimony whereof. I have hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the United States to be affixed. Done at the city of Washington, this 13th day of January, in the year of Our Lord, 1904, and of the Independence of the United States the one hundred and twenty-eighth. THEODOFwE ROOSEVELT. By the President JOHN HAY. Secretary of State. The following statement regarding the treaty wa3 Issued by the State Department The treaty which will go Into effect In a day or so. through the exchange of ratifications ef fected to-day, and by Its promulgation by the President of the United States, is tha result of nearly a year and a half's negotiation. Although relating in Its principal provisions to questions of commerce and navigation, removing restric tions which have hampered them both in China, it also treats of a number of questions of great importance to the people of the two countries. For example. It defines the rights and privileges of the diplomatic and consular officers and of American citizens, especially missionaries, resid ing China, and Insures the latter enjoyment of rights which they have only had In the past practically by toleration. The treaty also deals with trademarks, copyrights and patents. In suring them a fair degree of protection in Cblna a thing which they have had very little of In the past. Perhaps the provision of the treaty which In terests most the public is the opening of two new localities In Manchuria to foreign trade the city of Moukden and the town of An- Tung, or Shao, as it is frequently called, on the Yalu River. It Is to be noted In this connec tion that the Japanese and Chinese treaty, the ratifications of which were exchanged yester day at Peking, secures also to lnternationil trade the opening of the port of Tatung Kou. about thirteen miles below An-Tung, and at the mouth of the Yalu. It Is highly probable that the presence in these localities at an early date of American consular officers and those of other nationalities for all the nations having treaties with China acquire by our treaty, and that with Japan, the right to establish consulates at these placeswill greatly tend to the establishment of order In this much disturbed border land of China, and will powerfully contribute toward lnsurinp the principles of the open door. to which this country stands Irrevocably comm't well as aiding In insuring the lntesrrlty r- Chtaw and Its administrative control over its Manchurian provinces. The exchange of ratifications took place at the State Department by appointment at 11 o'clock. The Chinese Minister was accompanied by his secretary. Everything had been arranged, and Mr. Conger had informed the department that thf Chinese government placed an exchange copy of the treaty In h. hands yesterday. This is held to be equivalent to the delivery of the document to the United States government as required by the treaty itself. So Secretary Hay and the Chinese Minister joined to-day In the signature of the protocol, reciting the fact that ratifications had been exchanged. The Chinese Minister will receive a copy of the treaty by the State Department, which he will forward to his government for deposit In the imperial archives In Peking, and when Mr. Congers copy reaches Washington It will be placed in the State Department Library. The treaty is now an accomplished fact, and ft remains only to appoint the necessary con sqls at Moukden and An-Tung. The President has selected these consuls from men of expe rience already in the consular service, and con sequently able to open the new field to trade with the least possible delay. Their names will bo sent to the Senate as soon as Congress makes provision for their salary, which the State De partment hopes will be done speedily. It is re garded as extremely desirable that such rights ps the United States has acaulred in Manchuria. as to China shall be fully established and as serted in advance of any possible war that might affect that vast territory to the extent of a change of sovereignty. The Tirr.es's Peking cor respondent, telegraphing under yesterday's date, says that the Chinese Minister at Tokio. at the request of the Japanese Foreign Office, tele graphed the following communication to Prince Ching The second Russian reply to the Japanese pro posals has been received at Toido, but it is un favorable and cannot be accepted by Japan, who will, unless Russia recedes, be compelled promptly to resort to a.s. In view of euoh an eventuality Japan urgee and expects China to maintain the strictest neutrality, to preserve order through the em pire, to guard the foreigners resident in the interior, and to take special care to preserve order in the provinces of Shan-Tung and Yun- Nan, lest foreign powers may seize the pretext of disorder and make aggressive movements therein. The correspondent says that the dispatch has deeply impressed the Chinese, who now believe war to be inevitable. Ue adds that notes looking to the ratification of the treaty between China and Japan were exchanged yesterday afternoon, Mr. Balfour. the Premier, speaking at Man chester last night, declined to discuss the dif ferences between Russia and Japan, on the ground that such discussion would do little ser vice to the cause of peace. The Premier said Xo one can contemplate hostilities between two great civilized countries without feelings of misgiving- and depression. The Premier added that Great Britain would carry out to the fullest extent all of her treaty obligations. W. St. John Brodrick, Secretary for India, speaking at Guildford, said he hoped war would be averted. The government, he said, would do its utmost to promote a peaceful solution of the difficulties, but that if its effort failed Great Britain would 6eek to localize the effect of the conflict. Mr. Balfour's guarded statement is commented on by this morning's newspapers as an intima tion of the intention of the government to ac cord full support to Japan if circumstances arise which would call into action the Anglo-Japanese treaty. JANUARY 12. 1904. ALBANIANS IX ARMS. i Four Thousand Opposing Reforms Sarafoff at Rome. Vienna, Jan. 11. According to a dispatch from Sarajevo, Bosnia, to the 'Neut lie Presse, four thousand Albanians haw closed the road between Prizren, eighty-eight miles from Monastir. and Scutari, the capital of the vilayet cf the same name, their intention be ing to oppose the new gendarmerie organized under the Austro-RuHsUin reform scheme. A dispatch from Cettinje says that the gov ernment of Montenegro has decided to take steps for the immediate expulsion of ail Albanians. According to an unconfirmed report from Us kub, the Servian Deputy Archimandrite, Wassil, was shot by Albanians at the Detchlni Monas tery. It was expected that the Deputy Archi mandrite would succeed the late Monsignor Flrmllian, Bishop of Uskub. Rome, Jan. 11. Boris Barafoff, the Mace donian revolutionary leader, whose arrival in Rome the press here erroneously announced on January 3, arrived in this city last night. One of the objects of his visit Is to induce General Ricciottl Garibaldi to lead an expedition, hav ing for Its object the liberation of Macedonia from Turkish rule, similar to the expedition which Garibaldi headed at the time of the Greco-Turkish War. Sarafoff had an interview to-day with the leaders of the supporters of the Macedonian cause here. He said he wished to inform the Italian government that Macedonia was not satisfied with the Auatro-Russian action, and that a new revolution would break out next spring if all the powers who signed the Treaty of Berlin do not intervene and cause the grant ing of autonomy to- Macedonia. Sarafoff declared that the insurgents were ready for any step, and prepared to go to any extremity. He said that one of the objects of his visit to Rome was to learn what support the Vatican authorities would give his followers In Macedonia, and that the Orthodox Christians of the Greek Church In Macedonia were even prepared to embrace the Roman Catholic faith, as, he dei'lared. the late Pope Leo most anx iously desired. Barafoff is being closely watched by the Ital ian police. CUB AX S RATIFY TREATY. Measure Xot Debated PlatLsiviend ment Included. Havana. Jan. 11. The Senate, after clearing legislative business and being in readiness to adjourn until the spring, rushed the ratification of the so-railed permanent treaty with the United States. There was no debate, and the vote was ti'.ken simply by a show of hands and without a rollcall. Better Rtcio, Nationalist, demanded to be re corded la if negative, wo othtrs requested to be recorded SirnULtlvely. Tho treaty Includes all the provisions of the Platt amendment verbatim. This was the prop osition of the Cuban government, made because of the desire eventually to eliminate the amend ment from the constitution and so remove the cause of the constant criticism of the makers of the constitution for accepting euch an amend ment from the United States. It Is regarded as immaterial whether the reiuircnients and re strictions of the Platt amendment be continued In the form of a constitution or of a treaty. The treaty was signed on M.iy L ISOB, but was not ratified with the other treaties between the United Siutus ami Cuba at the close of the last session o Congress. The Committee on For eign Relations held up the treaty until to-day, and then reported it by order of the Senate. There was no apparent opposition by the metn lers of the commit tee, but tho eommltti ap peared afraid of tho possible political cftect of its action. Th.- report recommended the ndop tlon of the treaty, stating th.-it it would not change the political status or the relations be tween Cuba and the United States In any man ner. Kuhrman then, according to his confession, made a short circuit of some electric wires around a bundle of oiiy cotton waste and thus started the blsse. BUCHANAN COMFIRMED. MINISTER TO PAXAMA. The Nen Republic Formally Recog nized by the Senate. FKOM TM TRIBCNTC EtliAC. Washington, Jan. 11. The confirmation of William I. Buchanan aa Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Panama, which wai accomplished nnally to day with only sixteen Democratic votes in oppo sition, is, regarded as extremely gratifying, con stituting, as it does, a formal re -osmition by the Senate of the new republic This nomination was sent to the Senate on De cember 12 and confirmed five days later, but on the llth Senator Morgan moved to reconsider the action of the Senate, on the ground that the nomination had not received sufficient considera tion, and since that time the question has been rending. The molion of Senator Lodge, made to day in executive session, to lay on the table the motion of the Senator from Alabama, was promptly carried by a vote of 38 to IG. and re moved all doubt, if any had existed, regarding the attitude of the Senate toward the naw re public. Added significance Is given by the small num ber of Democratic Senators who rallied to Sen ator Gorman's call to do everything possible to prevent formal recojrnition of Panama. Al though nearly twice that number of Democratic Senators are in the city, only sixteen were pres ent this morning, when, it was understood, the question would come to a vote, thus showing how halfhearted Is the support which Mr. Gor man is receiving in his efforts to lead his Demo cratic colleagues against the canal policy of the administration. There is further significance in the similarity. In so far aa numbers go, between the total Dem ocratic vote and the poll of Senators on that side of the chamber on the question of ratifying the treaty made recently by Senators Dubois and Carmack. It will be remembered that the poll showed only seventeen Democratic Senators who were willing to pledge themselves against the ratification of the treaty, and, while the record of pairs may show a larger number of Democrats opposed to Mr. Buchanan con firmation, their opposition was of such a half hearted character us to lead them to stay away from the session, at which they knew they would be called on to place themselves on rec ri. Generally speaking, the situation among the Democrats is simple. They are trying to con vince themselves that the administration vio lated International law in its relations with Pan ama and would be delighted to defeat the con struction of the Panama Canal, but, apart from a few extreme radloals. they well appreciate tha. any determined opposition to the canal would be opposition to the will of tho people and would niore likely than not prove harmful to their personal welfare in thlr States. The vote to-day was on party lines, with the exception that Senator ifcCreary, of Kentucky, voted with the Republicans. Mr. Buchanan now has full power to act for this government n nil diplomatic exchanges between the United States and the new republic. Senator Morgan took the floor when the BeiH ni went into executive to-day anl pro tested against the confirmation of Mr. Buchanan sis minister OB th ground that the place to which the President had made the appointment v.as not in existence at the tim the nomination Was inf'le. anil could not l-e reatel without the co-operation of the Senate. Senator Bpooner an swered for the Republicans. He cited numerous authorities and precedents in support of the I'r'-Kldent's a'tlon. Senator Allison also spoke briefly in support of the administration, hll Senators Bacon and Culbersen favored the Dem ocratic contention. PLEA FOR SAX AXDRES. British Officials Sure That fftJttfa Will Xot Break Treaty. KING EDWARD APPEALS TO CZAR. London, Jan. 16. 1n the opinion of the British government the end of this week does not mark any change In the Far Eastern crisis, which more than ever keeps diplomatic circles in Lon don in a state of anxiety. The latest and, if it had been true, the most serious statement namely, that Russia intended to risk sending her Black Sea fleet through the Dardanelles received to-day a positive denial from the Foreign Office. Baron Hayashl. the Japanese Minister, visited Downing Street this afternoon, nnd was told that after making minute Inquiries the British authorities were convinced that the report was unfounded. Regarding the main issue. Baron Hayashi and the Foreign Office had no information. Not even the Czar's pacific utterances, however, can dis pel the fear which pervades British officials that Russia will not yield. King Edward continues to use his personal Influence to an almost un precedented extent to persuade the Czar to maintain peace, but the King's ministers appear to have practically given up hope that n. resort to arms can be averted, though even the most pessimistic persons do not look for nny culmina tion of the crisis within three weeks. The suggested Intervention, in the shape of tendering their good offices, on the part of other powers is now universally declared here to be quite impossible. How determined Japan is to face all the even tualities can be judged from the fact that she is negotiating in England for the construct of four battleships, not two battleship, as pre viously reported. The negotiations are not yet dosed, but the contract is likely to be taken up by the largest English firm within a week. The firm In question Kays that it is satisfied Japan is able to carry on a possible war long enough to pay for and use the vessels, which necessarily could not be ready under two years. The Spectator now regards vt as inevi table, in which ft merely follows up Its own significant -sruiBnt that 'a Russo- Japanese war would, be. to Great Britain's ad vantage, so long an Great Britain is only art onlooker and while th straggle does not in volve any other power. The Spectator has previously pointed out -in guarded language tnat surh a war was likely to leave both Russia and Japan crippled, neither gaining a great advan tage over the other, which suggest the deduc tion current In official circles here, that in this event Great Britain would he in a better posi tion to foster her sphere of influence In the Far East, unmenaced by the fear of Japan be coming a too paramount power in that quarter of the globe. Baron Hayashi said humorously to-night Great Britain and America might -li raise a. subscription In our behalf, for if war results and we win. they are bound to benefit by it. LAMGER GUARD AT SEOUL. IC Such reports as the State Department has received through its va rious agencies in Europe and the East are summed up in the expression that the resources of diplomacy hive not yet been exhausted in the Far Eastern situation. It ia expected that Rus sia will delay several day at least before mak ing anfver to the last Japanese note, and It Is said at the State Department that this note con tains no time limit, but Pimply hints that an early answer will be acceptable. Butioro testified that he first met York in 1900. when he paid him 5 for a duplicate citizenship certificate, and later obtained another for the same price, the name being left blank. York would give witness an order on the clerk for the certificate. 1 would pretend to be looking for a rubber and drop the money In the drawer of the table. said the witness, and other times I would hand it M York across the hall, but always so no one could see me do It. A dozen certificates of naturalization, all beating Italians' name., were Identified by Hunoro as ones he had purchased from York, paying 0 for each. All wrf turned over to him by York, prop erly executed, bearing the signature of the clerk of the United Stat-s District Court and seal of the court, name betas, left blank. Ha purchased about seventy-five or it hundred certificates from York. York used to take blank certificates to the home of the witness. GOLD BRICK SWINDLERS. Cuntiniwd from fourth pugr. gold brick la shown around without reserve. It is submitted to the most careful tests by any one who la inttrestei enough in It to take the trouble. There can be no manner of doubt re garding its being the real thing, for it actually ia. When the victim is lured to his fate and the money has changed hands, the real brick accompanies the swindler to parts unknown, while the one the countryman taites to the mint, with exaggerated precautions for Its safety, proves to be only brass. This Is the course pursued in the case of easy marks. When the quarry proves more wary a more extensive campaign is conducted. Hav ing brought the game to the point described above, it ia possible that the intending- purchaser of the gold brh k insists upon a further test by some one more expert than the local wiseacres. Perhaps the .swindler Onda It better to suggest this very thing in order to lure the victim on. He the C'lil brfa k man porslst3 in warning the farmer and decrying any confluence In himself, a perfect Stranger. He suggests what looks like the essence of fairness, namely, that the brirk shall Le taken to a neighboring town and there submitted to the United Slates assayer for a final examination. The swindler wffl not take no for an answer. Go they must So they go. The United States assayer is found to be a gray bearded man of studious aspect. His office has his name on the door, with United States Assay Office in imposing gilt letters. The as sayer Is surrounded by rucibles, scales, tools and mystery. He is very busy and rather brusque. He says he is tired of testing gold bricks for mere thanks. He demands a heavy fee and gets it. Then he takes the gold brick, submits it to various tests, pronounces it the purest gold and turns to his work. To conclude the story quickly, the victim finds no United States assayer tberc when he comes back from his trip to the mint. The assoyer is helping his Mead, the gold brick swindl.r, in some other part of the country. The trick is varied to suit the various cases. Sometimes the brick tested is the real gold brick and the test is made before UM sharp eyes of the victim. Then the as sayer changes the brick for the bogus one by some quick sleight of hand. Th- result is al ways the same. Tht- museum at the mint is the final r. -sting place of the goto lri- k. Another rural individual gn.-s away wailing. Still the ancient swindle brings grist to the mill of the swindlers. About the only thint that hi be said in fa vcr of a general service pension, such as is pro ond In tli- bill introduced by Senator Dollivcr, i that It I not mi bad now aw It would have been ten years ago. Th.- present pension law is so liberal that any honest veteran who has any need for a pension can have one. and many a dishonest veteran is able to take advantage of Its provisions to get a pension when he is not in need and in no ie incapacitated. A service pension of 12 a month to the few who are not now enjoying the government's bounty would perhaps not overwhelm the Treasury. An the turn of the tide In pension expenditure under th present law appears to have been reached, and a slight decrease noted, it seems to ha in order to provide new outlet for government money, for it would never do in the world to let the business of the pension attorneys go on decreasing through the failure of '.'ingress to provide an unending strenni of client. But whether the cyst be small or great, the principle of a service pension is vicious. I patriotism to lie appraised on a cash basis Is every man who shouldered a musket at his covntTT's call, irrespective of his needs or his wounds, going to become a hanger-on of the Treasury The pension attorneys want this, and a ienttment has len artfully worked up in Its favor among veterans who probably have not carefully thought out all that it Implies. But we do not believe that th rreat body of brT and patriotic men, who are proud of their part In saving the Union, wish to lower the standard of devotion for future generations and teach the world that men who do not need pewrtisi thick that they inun be pubsidized for having been patriotic W do not believe they cars thus to cheapen their service. To the veteran who for any reason needs aid, and to Lose dependent upon him. a grateful country will erar bs delighted to minister. The coun try hi net yet prepared, however, for the doc trine that any citizen who merely does his duty thereby acquires a title to the alms of the tax payers, his fellow citizens. Thousands of ninety day soldiers wouid. under this bill. be entitled ro pensions -who never were in a battle and vno, so far as th war Is concerned, are Just kb well , physically and financially, as their fellows who did their duty In civil life. They j'.re mostly worthy men. who point with pride to their names on tbe army lists. But to make ai rh service an excuse for unneeded pensions hi to cheapen It, and also cheapen the pension list and detract from the distinction of those who hold an honorable plare on It by reason of t ' i-clal sofferlog Another phase of the matter to be considered 1 the precedent which such a measure would HMahMah for the veterans of other wars. We 1 ready see the tendency to demand for the participants In the little Spanish affair all the rtTilf which have been accorded l those who fought through the Civil War. How long would It be after the passage of the Do liver Ml before every militiaman who got as near th Cuban barrleflelds as Chlekamanga or Joined u '''' triatalial procession across Porto Rioo would be demanding a life pension in rec ognition of his sacrifices for hia country The Treasury can doubtless endure the proposed drain upon It. but can it endure the establish ment of the Idea that, instead of citizens owing freely their services to the government, the government owes a living, regardless of his ability to support himself, to every citizen who ever by any chance dons its uniform for ninety days COXYICTB OX THE ROADS. ioort roads are worth all and more than all that they cctrt under the operation of the law which provides for State and county co-opera tion in New-York. But if tnere is a way of lessening the expense without impairing the quality of the work or harming any interest it ought to be adopted. The consequence would be not a reduction of the amount of money ap plicable to the purpose, but an increase in the number of miles Improved. There is reason to believe that object might be attained by the em ployment of convict labor, with great advantage to public and prisoners. In Rome Western and Southern States this policy baa been Increas ingly pursued within the h-v few years, and official reports of Its success are not contra dicted by other testimony. During the last summer the experiment was made in Schenec tfldy County, to the satisfaction of the local authorities, -vre learn from an interesting ac ccunt of it in The Municipal Journal and En gineer. After an investigation of the subject by a committee of the Board of Supervisors, a con tract was made with the town of Glenve for the macadamizing of a particularly bad piece of road, and in the course of seven mouths, with an average force of twenty prisoners from the county Jail, two and a half miles were put into excellent condition. The specifications pre scribed by the State where State aid is fur nished ere strictly followed, but the county and town bore all the expense, which, how ever, wi not g.vater than their share would have been under the provisions of the Iligbie- Armstrong law. One guard to eight prisoners was found to be enough, the men, as a rule, were cheerful and industrious, end the citizens suffered no annoyance or apprehension. Occa sionally a convict was Indisposed to exert him self, but he 6Oin changed his mind after being put on short rations. The committee made it a polnr, when a prisoner became noted for faiih ful service and good behavior, to give him em ploy rneut at current wages when his sentence expired. The official report frankly concedes that some questions were not completely solved by this brief experiment on a email scale, but in general the results fully justined the expecta tions aroused by similar operations in other parts of the country. It has long been a grave and at times a really distressing question how to find employment for prisoners without putting them Into harmful competition with free labor. To keep them In idleness Is a cruelty to them and a heavy bur den on the community. Iload building Js work which needs to be intelligently supervised, but otherwise requires littie Etcill. It is not work In which craftsmen would dislike to 6oe convicts employed. It Is more likely to be congenial than obnoxious to the convicts themselves, since it givs them some of the advantages of lib erty, while at the same time it tends to eradi cate criminal propensities. The chance of es cspes Is small, both because of the watcn kept and because a man under sentence for a com paratively light offence Is not often Inclined to accept such a risk of having his term of im prisonment extended. Undoubtedly the plan Is subject to some objections, and it Is possible that they might prove more serious In this State than they have been found to be in the Yest and South, though we see no reason to accept that hypothesis. At all events, the question is deserving of attentive consideration, for It seems to contain at least a partial solution of an embarrassing problem and to hi' adapted to the promotion of great public improvement. f'RLSIDEXT ELIOT OX LIBERTY. In his address to college men at the reception of the Brooklyn Tnlversity Club, on Friday evening, President Eliot took up a question which has been before discussed by other lead ers of public opinion, and came to the same conclusion, that true American liberty is gravely menaced by associations of employers on the one hand and employes on the other. His ad mirable and impreHslve utterance should have great Influence In arousing educated men to the sinister meaning of the present day drift to grind individual liberty and crush out individ ual opportunity between the upper and nether millstones of Intolerant and exclusive organ izations. Educated men have been too much in clined to accept standard of business ethics as they found them, enter the service of liberty de stroying corporations that offered them advance ment, and make terms with liberty destroying labor union. when it would conduce to their business success. The Brooklyn men who heard President Eliot's calm, clear and convincing ex position of the present state of affairs must have bans aroused to a new appreciation of the gravity of the task which they have to preserve freedom, a task which, in spite of warnings, they and other happy-go-lucky Americans are prone to estimate lightly. It is somewhat startling to find President Eliot quietly announcing, not as a figure of speech, but v. an actual simple fact, that In Boston to-day there Is less liberty than there was in 177.. Our ancestors fought King George because he would not give them enough liberty in that year. They endured a long war, and then established a government with a consti tution to secure the blessings of liberty to them selves and their posterity. Less liberty for their posterity now In Boston than when they r-roltd against a petty tax on tea, which inter fered with nobody's comfort or ability to earn a living' where and as he chose Yet, If we con sider, we shall pee that the statement is liter ally true. King George never dreamed of such interference with the colonists at the free citi zens of the United States and the common wealth of Massachusetts and of every other commonwealth in th land dally endure at the hands of Irresponsible combinations which have usurped the power of telling them who may build their house and at what price, whom they may employ and at what wages. It haa become a well known fact that in many cities the workers and the employers in the building trades are in a combination to defraud and tyrannize over the citizens. When a house Is to be built a corrupt circle decides who Is to bid for it at an exorbitant price and what bogu bids are to be put In to support It. The owner is helpless. If he rebels he can find no other contractor to do the work, or, If he does, a strike will put a stop to the endeavor. Similar conditions exist in other lines of bnsi nf. Between the tyrannical rule of the trust on the one hand and the labor union on the other, whether the two work in opposition or In harmony, the average citizen Is helpless. Every action of hi life is controlled by these forces. He Is subjected by them to extortion hln enn- Tenlence, his business, even his health and iife, are ruthlessly sacrificed to their prerogative for which they are more eelnsh, and more ambi tious, and more unscrupulous than King George ever was for th power and prestige of the British Crown. It Is time for educated mea and men of Colonial ancestry to awaka to th danger, and President Eliot performs a public service when he oses his grwt Influence wrer tbcai to work for the aafaguardlofrr.tbcr NKW-YOHK DAILY TRIBUNE, SUNDAY. JANUARY 17. 1904. than the recovery Amprioan liberty from the despotism -whirl has grown up within our own borders. IV IX ADEQUATE PENALTY. Yesterday's issue of The Tribune told in graphic language the story of a runaway in Fifth -a ye. A wine merchant's heavy delivery wag-on, drawn by two big Normandy horses, Ktood baited at Thirty-nlnth-st., while the driver went into a nearby shop to collect a bill. The horses took fright at some street noise and broke on a run down Fifth-aye. Their wild career was not checked until they reached Thirty-second-st On the way down they had thrown traffic in the avenue into a panic, scattered pedestrians, smashed into two passenger vehicles and in jured their occupants, and incidentally endan gered many lives. The driver guilty of leaving the team unwatched on the sidewalk was ar rested, and was discharged on payment of a 5 line. We cannot but think his dismissal with such a penalty a burlesque both on law and on com mon sense. As the event proved, his leaving his team un watched was palpable criminal neg ligence. He had no right to endanger the lives of others in order to do an errand clearly incon sistent with his duties as a teamster. If he was instructed by his employer to collect bills and take chances on the good behavior of his horses, he and the employer were equally guilty of criminal recklessness. Both should be held responsible, in that case, for the injuries their folly was the means of inflicting on innocent passersby. The public is entitled to adequate protection against street perils, and to adequate redress. if those perils are due to the gross and deliberate carlesuess of delivery wagon drivers or deliv ery wagon owners. If a fine of 5 Is the maxi mum penalty for such an offence as that com mitted yesterday in Fifth-aye., our criminal laws should bo revised. They do not now af ford sufficient safeguards against criminal neg lect. i AMBLERS A. YD LAWYER. It is announced that Mr. Richard Cauneld, of Saratoga and New-York, having succeeded in escaping the processes of the criminal courts of this State, has testilied his gratitude to Mr. John B. Stauchfleld, his savior from the toils, by a substantial honorarium of 30,. Saving a gambler comes high. We congratulate Mr. Stanchtield 011 a restitution which enables him to secure that class of clients and command so rich a fee in a case which, to judge from Its Ignominious conclusion, could not have been excessively difficult. Mr. Stanchfield would doubtless have defended a common thief in a much more harder case for far less. If he had consented to lower his dignity by defending a common thief at all. Probably it Is only un common rascals whose freedom from just pun ishment ho would seek to secure. Thirty thousand dollars la a pretty large fee for getting dismissed without trial an indict ment for simply keeping a gambling house. Perhaps it Is based on the theory that the gains of the gambler are ill gotten, and that it is only fair that ho should divide the swag with the lawyer who can keep him going. Anyhow, a gambler cannot expect that a lawyer of high reputation, one who has been a candidate for Governor, will let himself bo mixed up In low associations without plenty of soap with which to wash off the taint afterward. The presume which that remarkable nation has gained and hold has probably never been rivalled by that of any other la similar cireum itancea. Men who arc not yet willing to be con sidered id remember when Japan was scarcely open to the world, and had scarcely begun to emerge from barbarism the world gen erally spoke of Japan much as of P.unnah ami Zanzibar and the Fiji Islands. lien still young remember when Japan threw off the fetters of modht'valisin Und adopted a constitutional and representative government. It seems only the other day that extra-terrltorialism was abolished, and all other discriminations, and Japan was treated as the legal peer of other nations. It was two years ago this month that Great Britain took the unprecedented step of making a treaty of alliance with Japan, treat ing the latter with a respect and esteem similar to that which France pays to Roosta in the Dual League or lint which the members of the Triple Alliance pay to each other. To-day, then. Japan stands unchallenged among the great powers Of Hie world. She Is the peer of any of them in legal standing. In sentiment and sympathy she actually outranks at least one of them. There can, we think, lie no doubt thai the preponderance of sympathy the -world over is with her and against her ad versary in the present quarrel. That is to say, Europe and America side with nn Asiatic power of the yellow race against a. Puiopean power largely of the white race. That Is an extraor dinary state of affairs, bat the reason is not dif ficult to discover, it is partly because Japan Is seen to be. fighting the battle of civilization and progress. She is contending for the Inter ests of Europe and America, against Influences that would Impair them. Bat that is not all. Japan Is also seen to be worthy of the esteem she is receiving. That is perhaps the dominant feature of the case. In wise statesmanship, lv shrewd diplomacy, in generous spirit, In earnest desire for peace with justice and honor, and in Intelligent self-control Japan has won the ad miration of the world. It Is to be doubted if any attar nation In similar circumstances has ever acted more creditably In the face of. such conditions the old cry of tho yellow peril rings false. It is still raised, of course, by Japan adversary and would-be oppressor, and by a few others who formerly o committed themselves to it that they cannot now help repeating it. But It Is vain. The whole influenix- of Japan, both in herself and In respect to China and the other yellow peo ples, is so beneficent that other nations are in clined to ay, If ihis be 'peril, let us have more of it Moreover, with vhe examples of Poland, of Finland and of Armenia before it, and with the threat to male another Finland of the whole Scandinavian Peninsula nnd another Po ls p rfc Pnrti ft -rorld hi beginning to ask If the Slavic peril is not greater than the 'yellow one. The necessity of such a choice is not to be considered yet if it were to be, there are plenty of judicious thinkers who would pre fer to see China controlled and wakened and roused to action by Japan rather than by Russia. It may be that neither would be a menace to the world. It seems certain that the former would be the more auspicious for progress and civiliza tion. Reply to Japan's Xote X early Ready Negotiation May Go On. St. Petersburg. Jan. 18. It Is already practi cally certain that Russia will not accept Japan's last propositions as an entirety. Russia is ready to agree to certain points, but on others, the Foreign Office believes. Russia cannot yield. The officials are of the opinion that the way is open for continuing the negotiations, and there is no indication that Russia will seek to delay her answer, which probably will be ready .i a few days. The Czar continues lo talk of peace, and the Czarina Dowager, in conversation, remarked War is a horrible thing. There v ill not be war. In the meanwhile Viceroy Alexieff and Baron de Rosen, as well as the Foreign Office, are studying the Japanese document. Army and navy circles continue pessimistic. The beat feature of the situation is the fact that the Japanese reply has In no sense the character ot. an ultimatum. v f u-hl in pacific terms, does not fix a time limit, and the acceptance by Russia of certain of the propo sitions mark an advance toward a settlement. Many rumors arc in circulation. Including a report that a naval fight has occurred at Vladi vostok. Another rumor indiiHtrlousl spread flsrlsrfis that the Czar, on partlns from aftoUeter Kurino on the occasion of the New Tear's reception, speaking In French, remarked The patience of KusHa Ist almost exhausted. To Fight for Other Xations' Princi ples as Well as Her Own. Iondon, Jan. 16. 10 frank language Huron Ilayn.shi. nfter consultation with the Foreign Office to-night, summed up the situation as fol lows I only hope the Czar will giv us jxce, but my hopes are not strong. If we go to war it will be for Issues on which both America and Eng land have Insisted diplomatically. We have te ceived no pledges from any country that in the event of defeat it will tep in and save us from being absorbed by Russia. We cannot count even in extremities on the armed .support of any nntion In the world, f would be i struggle to the death. Perhaps we are not strong enough to fight Russia. There are two opinions about that. Karon Hayashl Intimated that he thought Japan was bound to be beaten In the end, and continued If we were beaten Russia would take Corea and Manchuria by right of conquest, and pos sibly Japan. No power on earth could then dis lodge her from Central China and all the Far East. I am sure It is better to go to war when you know you are right, fven If defeat is pos sible, than to see your independence submerged under a continual aggression that Is bound to absorb you eventually. Nothing can avert war between Russia and Japan in futur years, even If peace is procured now, so long as Russia pursues her present Far Eastern poliry. The American action in enforcing the opening of the Miinchuriar. ports was a splendid example of honest diplomacy. It was a straightforward step, which contrasts favorably with Russian methods. No other nation, except Great Britain, when the British Admiralty bought the two Chilian warships, has taken any practical step to live up to its diplomatic demands upon Rus sia anent the Far Kast. We believe we are now fighting a diplomatic battle in behalf of America, and Great Britain, but If only wir can settle it we know We shall receive assistance from neither. We are prepared to fight our own bat tles and take the consequences. HOPES FALL IN PARIS Japan Thought to Have Pressed Her Demands Too Far. Paris. Jan. 16. Flt'lM THE TRIBI'NE nfltEAC.l Washington, Jan. 10. Senator Hanna, chair man of the Republican National Committee, ar rived in Washington to-day, and immediately Issued the call for the national convention. The expedition with which this matter was finally disposed of is conceded by prominent Republi cans to have bees due to the rumors to which the delay gave rise and to the forcible manner in which they were brought to the attention of the executive committee. Although the date of the call i later than on any occasion in the last quarter of a century, with the single exception of l v '.' when the call vas issued on January it having been cus tomary to issue it about December IS any dis position to criticize has given place to expres sions of gratification that the desired end is finally accomplished. Early in the day there was some comment on th facts that late last night the csslstant sec retary of the National Committee gave out an interview In which he attributed the delay to I. -k of Information concerning the manner of selecting delegates from the District of Colum bia thuftbe urn evening Senator Hanp.u gave out a Statement at l'ittslurg. allKing the neces sity of Investigating Chicago hotel rates as one Of his reasons for postponing the .-all and the awe day Senator Scott, a member of the execu tive committee, ma'- 1 statement explaining that Mr. Hannu's ill health and preoccupation With private affairs had prevented action. This evening, however, hi multiplicity of conflict ing reasons Is lost sicht of, and expressions -if satisfaction that the call is jut. are to be heard. The party leaden desire not only to hold early conventions, but to hare ample time In which to attend to the preliminaries, thuj avoiding the dancer f contests and confusion in the national convention. The issue of the call will permit of the usual formalities in every State, and will enable the active workers to begin their prepara tions at once. The text f the call la as follows To Urn Republican Elector of the United State In accordance with established custom and in obedience to instructions of the national con vention of 1h, the Republican National Com . directs that a national convention of dele gated representatives of the Republican party be held at the city of Chicago, in the State of Illinois, for the purpose of nominating- candi dates for President sad Vice-President, to be voted for at the Presidential election on Tues day. November 8, 1901, and for the transaction of such other business as may properly come before it. and said convention shall assemble at 11 o'clock noon on Tuesday, the -Ist day of June, 1901 The Republican electors of the several States and Territories, the District of Columbia. Alaska and Indian Territory, and all other electors, without regard to asl political affiliations, who believe In the principles of the Republican party and indorse its policiies, are cordially Invited to unite under this call in the selection of candi dates for President and Vice-President. Said national convention shall consist of a number of delegates' at-large from each State equal to double the number of I'nited States Senators to which each State is entitled, and for each Representative-at-large in Congress, two delegates-at-large. From each Congressional district and the District of Columbia, two dele gates. From each of the Territories of Ari zona. -Mexico, Oklahoma and Hawaii and Indian Territory, six delegates. From Alaska, four delegates. For each delegate elected to said convention an alternate delegate shall be elect ed to act In case of the absence of the delegate, such alternate delegate .to he elected at the time ami In the manner of electing the delegate. All delegates shall be elected not less than thirty days before the meeting of the national convention. Delegates-at-large shall be elected by popular State and Territorial conventions, of which at least thirty days' notice shall have been published in some newspaper or newspa pers of general circulation in the respective States and Territories. The Congressional district delegates shall be elected by conventions called by the Congres sional Committee of each district. In the manner of nominating the candidate for Representative In Congress In said district, provided that in any Congressional District where there is no Repub lican Congressional Committee the Republican State Committee shall appoint from among the Republican residents in such district a commit tee for the purpose Of calling a district conven tion to elect delegates to represent said district. The election of delegates from the District of Columbia shall be held under the direction and supervision of an election board composed of Mr. Chapin Brown. Mr. George H. Harries and Mr. John F. Cook. The board shall have au thority to fix the date of such election and to arrange all details an 1 regulations Incident thereto, an.l shall provide for a registration of the votes as cast, such registration to include the name nnd residence of each voter. The Territorial delegates shall be elected In the manner of nominating candidates for Dole gates in Congress, and delegates from Alaska and Indian Territory shall be elected by popu lar convention. All notices of contests shall be submitted in writing, accompanied by a printed statement, setting forth the grounds of contest, which shall be Hied with the secretary of the national com mittee twenty days prior to the meeting of the national convention. Contests will be acted on by the national con vention in the order at the date of tiling of notk and statement with the secretary. PERRY S. HEATH. Secretary. If. A. HANNA. Chairman. When Admiral Evans's fleet sailed for the Orient from Honolulu sev enty-five men from different vessels were left behind. It was supposed at the time that they would return in a few days to the naval station, and then be sent over to join the fleet by the first transport. Only eleven men appeared, and several of these were captured by police. It is certain that sixty-four have deserted, and the theory is that most of them have succeeded In leaving the islands for Port Arthur or Vladi vostok, and there getting places with good pay as gunners iv the Russian navy and at the forti fications. While Admiral Evans's ftVet was at Honolulu local papers published a cable dispatch from China saying that Admiral Alexieff was offer ing high salaries for American and British gun ners. I HOPS SIX FOR IIAZIXG. Sophomore Class at Wesley an Uni versity Criticises the Faculty. Mlddletown, Conn.. Jan. President Ray mond of Wesleyan University to-night suspend ed fix members of th- sophomore class until the midyear examinations In February. The students are charged with being connected with the hazii of a fellow Student la.st month. The students suspended are Arthur K. Dearborn, Mlddletown Clarence B. Hancock, Syracuse, N. V. Arthur J. Hanloi . Canaan, Conn. Arthur J. Munroe, BratUeboro, vt Frank H. Byrett, Mont. lair. N. J. and Ralph M. Ce. Totten ville, N. Y. The students are ordered to leave Mlddletown not later than Saturday night. The trouble had Its beginning in th.- attempt of a number of sophomores to base Prank B. Taylor, of Cambridge, Mass., on the night of December 10 last. On their first attempt to en ter his room Taylor frightened away his tor mentors with a revolver, but they returned later In the. evening and attempted to break down the door. Taylor, fearing he would be injured, picked up a screwdriver and began to fight his way through the crowd. In doing so he struck Howard Richards, of New-Haven, just over the eye, Infill ting an Injury which resulted m Rich ards losing the sight of the eye. The affair was brought to the attention of the faculty, and to day's action resulted. The students, after learning of the siisponslona, held a meeting, at which they drew up resolu tions disapproving the action of the faculty on the grounds that to single out six men of the Class was unjust, there having been many more students Implicated in the hazing. JAPAN DEFERS CONFLICT, NEGOTIATIONS TO GO ON. Russia's Reply Unsatisfactory, but Does Not Warrant War. Tokio, Jan. 8. The Japanese government has practically determined to continue negotiations. It is dissatisfied with Russia's terms, but doea not feel warranted In issuing an ultimatum or breaking off negotiations, and will make another effort to secure their modification before resort ing to force. It is anticipated that the discussion will con sume a few weeks, and in this interim a breach of the peace is very improbable. The Elder Statesmen of Japan did not hold a conference to-day, but will probably meet to morrow. In the mean while the wildest rumors are current. The press unanimously demands that the gov ernment take decisive action, thereby prevent ing Russia from gatemg advantages by further dilatory tactics. The people repose confidence In the govern ment's ability to meet th situation. JAPAN TO KEEP COREA. Reported Terms of Far Reaching Russian Concessions. Berlin, Jan. B. The Tageblatfs Paris cor rfspendent learns that the French government has been informed that Russia's answer to Japan makes far reaching concessions respecting Corea, and that these concessions are equivalent to permitting the occupation of Corea by Japan, on lines somewhat similar to the position of Great Britain in Egypt, hut that Russia flnrly rejects any right of Japan to mingle in affairs in Manchuria. Paris. Jan. B. lt is learned that. In the opinion of the French government, there i 3 still a chansa of avoiding a conflict between Russia and Ja pan aa a result of a concession made by Russia in her last note. The dispatches which hay come to Parl3 from all Quarters to-day have been moat pessimistic, and the hopefulness of the government Js in strong contrast with them. It appears that Russia's concession rotates to the recognition of the preponderance of the in terests of Japan in Corea. This has been the crux of the question between the two powers up to the present moment. Just how far the concession goes It is Impossibla to learn, but th effect in Tokio. according to the Information ob tained, has been more satisfactory than the press dispatches show. In connection with Russia's concession, an odd and at the same time authoritative story la told regarding the cause oT the jwelopment of tha present situation. It appears that a misunder standing ocmiied between Viceroy AlexiefT and the Russian government, and that the note antedating the ore just submitted did not con tain a recognition of Japanese preponderating intlunce in any part of Corea. VEL.DEMERS. A. I CAUGHT IX FURIOUS STORM. The vessel was a regular dally passenger Packet. She made moderately good progress across the Straits, bound for Victoria, until Trial Island, off the entrance to the harbor, was abeam. Then a terrific cross sea was pelting the vessel, retarding her progress and making life uncomfortable for those aboard. Little fear j was manifested, however, until word came up j from below that the vessel was leaking. Inves- ' tigation showed that the waves on the wind- '. ward side had stove In a deadlight, through j which the water rushed in volumes, resisting all effort to stop it. Seeing the efforts futile, the safety at the passengers particularly the women and chil- j dren, was looked after, and all bo desired were ' X Off fron the Mmer In the boats. The ' heavily laden boats were thrown about wildly In the choppy sea. and one after another, after i succeeding in getting away from the vessel. ' were either capsized or swamped. ALL WOMEN AND CHILDREN LOST. The terrible fury of the storm is attested by the fart that not a woman or child of nil thos ' on board lived to tell th tale. An apparent di- ercnaney in numbers from the list of fatalities is accounted for by the fact that only the chil- j dren who paid half fare were on the passenger i list. In the mean time word had come from Vie- ' toria of the vessel's predicament. and powerful tugs were dispatched to render assistance. The j Richard Holyoke. in command of Captain Rob- i crt Hall, was the urst to reach the Clallam. I which had by this time careened partly over ' from the inrush of water, which had put the engines out of commission. The Holyoke reached the Clallam about 11 o'clock last night and about 1 a. m. succeeding In getting a hawser aboard, with which she started to tow the Clallam to safety. The dsJlam took a heavy j lurch, ar.l those remaining aboard were com- pelled to climb up the side to safety, finally i reaching the roof of the pilot house. SURVIVORS RESCUED BY TUG'S BOATS. Without a moment's hesitation the tug's boats were lowered and the work of rescue began At this point the tug Sea Lion. Captain Hunter arrive.d. and her mm rendered valuable as sistance. Before all the struggling people had been taken off the riallam began to break up and soon afterward went down. All possible assistance to the rescued people was given by the two shipmasters and their crews and the i tugs hurried to Port Townsend. The surviving i passengers and the remainder of the crew then ' took passage on the Dirigo. bound for Seattle STORY OF A SURVIVOR. W. H. Grimes, of Redmond, Wash . aboard the Clallam, bound for Victoria, gives a conciao I statement. The weather was. pretty rough. he i said, but we- had no suspicion of danger until MOM one forward said something about life pre servers. I went forward to Investigate, and there learned that the Clallam was making water rapidly. Th 1 oats were promptly manned and launched, and the women and chil- I dren and ruch re-ngers a desired to leave were placed in them, competent crown being In i charge. The boats made off from the steamer ' safely, but ore after another they capsized, nnd we v. er-- helpless to render them any assistance, They simply drowned before our eyes. In the I mean time crew and prissenpers were busy ball- i inp and trying to atop the leak, but without I success. The balling was kept up, however, and I Boon we were overjoyed to learn that a big tug had hold of us. The towboat started and made pretty good progress until It became apparent that the steamer v.as careening under us. Then j all hands went on deck, and as the ill fated packet lifted we gradually crawled up on her ex- posed side, from which the brave fellows from th Holyoke rescued most of us. i Prominent among thos- known to be aboard and unaccounted for Is Homer Swaney, iron and I steel plant promoter and owner of valuable iron properties in British Columbia. He boarded the vessel here and was not among the rescued. When the Clallam was launched at Tacoma, last April, the bottle of champagne was not I broken, but fell and slid down along the side of the vessel. Old seamen predicted that disaster j would overtake the vessel within a year, and It ' v.as said at the time that it would be a diffi- j cult matter to secure a crew to man her. Dunne de- llvered a broadside from the bench to-day against the sentiment reported to have ben expressed by District Attorney Jerome, of New- York, regarding the rough handling of crook. A law defying, crime inciting utterance from a public official charged with the preservation of the peace. was the opinion expressed by Judge Dunne of District Attorney Jerome' re ported plan Of treating lawbreakers. Judge Dunne gave utterance to this entlment aftr Robert K. Cantwefl, an attorney, had rep resented in the court that a prisoner who was asted and subsequently charged with com plicity in several murder and robberies had been roughly handled by the police. Men In Mr. Jerome's position should not be guilty of uttering suh Incendiary and ilrgl sentiments. continued Judge Dunne. It is most outrageous, unworthy of tfct iiun irvj disgrace to ills office. I iir sstonfjded 1 M' Jerome, as I have always believed himt be a vigorous prosecutor and an honest man. It . Imply Inciting police officers to commit crine. The opinion 1 have expressed about District Attorney Jerome is based on the assumption that h whs correctly quoted as saying that 'most of the men charged with crime with us, when brought into court, bear evidence of re sisting an offl'-er. We nee to it that these men do resist officers, or we force them to resist and then bring them in In fragments.' The interview referred to hns also been caus tically criticised by Mayor Harrison. The Mayor said advice to beat up prisoners rm with a poor grace from a law officer. In a subsequent interview. Mr. Jerome is quoted In reply to Mr. rrlson as follows I did not say that I Indorsed the methods of the Mew-York police in handling crooks, but I did say. and I know, that rough handling- ha abated crime to a grent extent. If good has been accomplished there is some excuse for the means employed. Mr. Jerome came to Chicago to deliver an ad dress at the. Merchants' Club. He will leave for New-York to-morrow morning. Jan. The Democratic State Com mittee, nt a meeting here to-day, indorsed a movement in favor of having the national con vention of the party nominate Richard Olney. of this city, for President of the United States. After speeches In praise of Mr. Olney's record hnd been made by Congressman William S. Mi Nary, chairman of the committee Charles S. Hrr.lln. of Boston, formerly Assistant Secre tary of the Treasury ex-Congressman John C. Crosby, of Pittsfleld, and other, resolutions were adopted Inviting Democrats throughout the country to work in favor of such a move ment. When the resolutions were first presented. however, Qerce opposition developed, and they were bitterly fought. The opposition was con ducted us though th Bry '-Williams men who rre on the committee were under orders to fight . Olney, and the dream of a solid New- England f m likely to IM destroyed. The resolu tfL i-Sw The Democratic State Committee of Massachu setts herewith place upon record its apprecia tion of the eminent services rendered the Demo cratic party and the nation by Richard Olney, and expresses Its firm conviction that under his leadership in the coining Presidential ram paU-i Important New-F.rmland States will swing over into the Democratic colmun. and the na tional party will a. hl.-ve a sweeping victory, Insuring a speedy reform of the abases following a continuance in power of the Republican party and the re-eafabliihment of those fundamental principles of government which that party has deliberately and flagrantly violated. To this end we Invite the co-operation of the Democrats of New-England and of the nation. These resolutions were introduced by Con gressman McXary. who classed Mr. Olney as one of the foremost Americans and foremost Democrat. 1 He thought that if th.- Democrats were to win this year they must carry the East ern States. It appeared, he said, that Mr. Oiney was strong In New- York and New-Jersey and that he would be acceptable to those States. New- York not having any candidate, the nom ination fa man from New-England, and that man Mr Olney. would have the immense advan tage to the Democrats of establishing a large Eastern area where the scales rou'il ha turned in favor of the Democratic nominee. Mr. Oiney would be Htrong In Illinois and Connecticut. In closing Mr. McNary thought that Mr. Oiney would receive at the polls the great independent vote of the country. Mr. Hamlln. In favoring the resolution, spoke in a strain similar to Congressman McXary. He referred to the advantages which would ac crue from nominating a New-England niaji. He traced Mr. Olney's career, and spoke of Mr. Olney's achievement in the Venezuela affair when he had forced England to arbitrate the Venezuelan question. He declared that as Sec retary of State under President Cleveland he had been the protector of the South American republics, when other administrations have been In effect their oppressors. Mr. Hamlin added Mr. Oiney is a man of sterling Democracy and of rugged character. Under his leadership several States of New- England may be counted upon for the Democrats. Under his leadership j the Democratic party will sweep the country. FRANCHISE TAX ADVANCE Increased Valuation Will Raise Levy About One-third. Albany. Jan. 9.-The action of the Board of Assessors of New-York City in greatly increas ing the assessed valuation of real estate in that municipality will materially affect the amount of special franchise taxes that corporations operating in that city will be required to pay ur.der the Ford law. It is probable that their , assessments will be increased about one-third I Of course, this is dependent on a decision of j the United States Supreme Coi-rt sustaining the I decision of the Court of Appeals of this state. which held the Franchise Tax law to be con stitutional. In the equalization of the valuation of real , estate in this State among the several counties I the State Board of Equalization has rated the valuation for New-York City at per cent that is, it has held that the local assessors val ued that class of property at 67 per cent of its actual or market value, in 1NT8 the local as sessors of New- York increased the total value of real estate from IU3MT.IR9 to 91181.. f-r0.826. an increase of 51.4.H93,247. or about one-third. The Special Franchise Tax law provides that the value of the special franchises shall be j fixed by the State Board of Tax Commissioners j at full value.- The courts, in construing the law. decided that the assessment should be at the rate at which other classes of real estate are assessed in the same locality. Under that i decision the assessments placed on franchises operated in New-York City will be reduced about one-thin. When the State Board of Equalization pre pares Its next equalization table the rate for New- York City 'will be increased in consequence of the Increased valuation made by the assessors of that city. It Is estimated that the next equal ization table will rate New-York at 75 instead of 67 per cent. Thus, in the readjustment of special franchise tax valuations in that city In the future the reduction will be about 25 in stead of 33 per cent. It is learned here to-day that the corporations of New- York City which are parties to the liti gation attacking the special franchise tax act in j the Federal Supreme Court are practically tha i enly large corporations which have not yet paid their taxes under the law. The amount of I money due from these corporations Is estimated at between ln.iOn.iiNj and SI'J... The exact figures cannot be ascertained, because the j amount due depends not only on the assessment j made, but also on reductions to be made under i the Court of Appeals decision and the additions I for Interest. In most up-State counties the cor j porations and the assessors have gone into court j and secured orders adjusting the assessments i pursuant to the Court of Appeals decision. It Is impossible to obtain a record of the corporations which have paid their tax, or the amounts paid j because that is a transaction local to th taa j district In which each franchise operates, th duties of the State Tax Commissioners ceasing i when they have valued the franchises. There are fly flatuies In the side of the mountain, from which f-mok pours in considerable volume, accom panied by a deep, rumbling noise. All the trees in the vicinity ar. blasted and splintered. Jan. 9 The steamer Provan. which arrived from Calcutta late last ninht. brought In the captain and rrew of the schooner G. A. Smith, of Rlchibucto. N. who were fouVl on their dismasted and sinking vessel about four hundred miles off the coast. The men were taken off the schooner with great difficulty, and within an hour after they were on board the steamer their own vessel foundered stern first. The Provan landed her commander. Captain Jones, at Algiers, seriously ill with Inflamma tion of the bowels, and came Into port under Chief Officer Ford. On her way across the At lantic she ran Into three separate storms, all from the west-northwest, the severest being that of Sunday last, which compelled the steamer to lay to for twenty-four hours. The Smith was sighted on Wednesday last, and on running down to her five men were seen huddled on the poop. The Provan was laid up to the windward of the little schooner, and the chief officer, the boatswain and three men put off in a lifeboat, which was rowed alongside the schooner. One by one the men dropped off Into j the sea and were hauled aboard. Before the last man left the wreck the schooner was set on fir, but this proved unnecessary, as she foundered within an hour. The men had been on the deck of the vessel without food or water for two clays, and had given up all hope of rescue. They will be sent to their homes in Nova Scotia by the British Consul.
