The educational establishment bill ou wheh leading members of the Senate and Assembly are said to have agreed, and widen is supposed to embody the filial views of the joint legis lative committee and to have received the Got ernor's approval, may not pass fo easily as some of its advocates expect. It might. In fact, be a risky proceeding to push through In a hurry, as hero is talk of doing, a measure of the Bret Importance relating to a matter us to which there baa been a wide divergence of official aad general opinion for years and until within a few days. We hope that most of those who have engaged iu the long contro versy will be ready t. admit that tnc proposed scheme has some excellent features. If enact ed and carried out lu good faith. It would eventually accomplish h veritable unification of school control, which has always been the earnest desire of Intelligent and disinterested citizens of this State. But it appear to us that in Its present form them may be o'ojectlona whica require careful consideration. Possibly they wauld prove less formidable than they now look. Perhaps It might lc found that an attempt to change the scheme materially would arouse fatal opiosition to any plan for getting rid of existing evils. In which case it would be judicious to weigh the comparative advantages of keeping on in the old way or of adopting a new way also faulty. At all events, Impartial discussion, inspired by a conscientious purp to do the best thing for the State, ou'bt to precede legislative action. The opinion is held by some lawyers of repute that Kegeuts of the University, elected for life In conformity with the statute, cannot be con stitutionally ejected from office at tbe pleasure of the legislature. If that question should bo formally raised by any of the Regents, or by anybody else, for that matter, thoe who like to make trouble under a pretence of helpfulness would infallibly repeat the shabby misrepre sentation that such Regeuts are selfishly re solved to keep their places at all hazards. The fact is that few of the Regents would person ally object to being lawfully relieved of the unsolicited duties which were Imposed upon them by the legislature and whiih they huve performed to the best of their ability at con siderable sacrifice. Still, the question of con stitutionality ought to be intelligently consid ered In advance, Instead of being left to pro duce, perhaps, serious embarrassment here after. There is another important consideration re lating to the Intrinsic merits of the plan pro posed. The ostensible desire of all who have joined in the educational dispute has been to take and keep politics out of tbe schools. But a moment's reflection suggests the Inquiry, per tinently raised In our Albany correspondence yesterday, whether the election of an entirely new board by the present legislature, and the selection of an entirely new superintendent by the present legislature, and the organization of an entirely new 6ystem under the present legislature, do not seem to put the whole school system of the State, secondary edui-a tlon as well as primary, more completely in the hands of the politicians than ever. Un doubtedly, fortunate results under such an ar rangement are attainable, and we hope that its sponsors are resolved to secure them. If a man fully qualified in all respects for the new commissionershlp of education should receive and accept tbe appointment there might be nothing to regret But if tbe legislature, either owing to unforeseen complications or by pre vious contrivance, should be compelled or per suaded to fall back on an unsuitable candidate the fixed condition of things for six years to come might easily be as bad as anything known hitherto. As for the apportionment of the Regents among the Judicial districts of the State, though its natural tendency would be to increase rather than diminish the danger of p litical interference in their selection, still. It is manifestly desirable on some accounts that the board should fairly represent the various parts of the commonwealth. For obvious reasons. Tbe Tribune Is reluctant to find fault with a plan of school administra tion which contains a promise of unification under a competent directing body aud of permanent relief from the distracting con troversy which it has earnestly endeavored to help compose in the only rational manner. We gladly acknowledge the good features of this latest measure, but we know that it ought to be dealt with deliberately, and our impres sion is that it may need to be amended in some particulars. .A.V IXSPIRIXO EXAMPLE. There is one phase of the unfortu nate business, though, on which the mind can dwell with pleasure and protit. Even yet, per haps, enough attention has not been directed thereto. In the beautiful heroism of those wbo bought to rescue the Imprisoned miners there is inspiration for the dullest soul. No one knew better than McCann. Taylor, Lysle and their associates the risks they ran. They were only too familiar with tbe consequences of past explosions. Afterdamp unquestionably meant more to them than to mos people, but they dreaded Its effects upon others rather than upon themselves. Tbe one thought which occupied their minds was the desolation with which nearly two hundred homes were threat ened. In an attempt to reduce this to the lowest possible minimum they were willing to imperil, and even sacrifice, their lives. Tbe world cannot honor such a spirit too much. If it had been practicable to witness what happened Inside the mine immediately after the explosion. It is pomtble that one might have been privileged to look upon equally noble, if ab-lutely futile, efforts. Though It Is an established fact that about one-half of the colliery disasters on record are the result of tbe carelessness of the miners, it Is also true that this weakness is characteristic of only a few, not of the many. It is known that a con rideraole proportion cf the men employed In coal mine, especially of those of American Mrth. show nm-h consideration for their fel lows and assistants. Roberts. In his book on the anthracite industry, furnishes numerous Illustrations of that iralt. We hope that District Attorney Jerome will not fail to notice the account of tbe remark of Patrolman Datton before Magistrate Ommea when he was reprimanded for clubbing a pris oner Didn't Jerome siy out In Chicago that we were to Ix-at our iidsouers It ought to luipre6a on Mr. Jerome miud the evil of reck less and Irresponsible utterance, especially on the part of n man in official position. We have nevrr sopposed tor a moment that Mr. Jerome rcnlly meant to advocate carnival of bead breaking on the part of the police either in New-York or Chicago, aud we advised our Chicago friends not to miud, when they got excited about his Incitement of their peace orticcrs to violence. We told them it was jnst a way Mr. Jerome had of overstating himself. Nevertheless, if Mr. Jerome's remarks had any effect at all, it wad Inevitable that they should be In the direction of lawlessness, and It is now apparent that they did have that effect. One swallow does not make a summer, and the excuse of one putrolnian is not to be taken as evidence that the whole force is going to jro clubbing In conscious accord with Mr. Jerome's advice. Dalton's remark, however, indicates that the District Attorney's words have been taken account of by the police. They mny not, tbey probably do not, prompt delib erate brutality, but tlipy come to mind as a ready excuse for brutality Indulged in under some other provocation. To that extent they nre demoralizing. They weaken self-control. They also tend to diminish the respect which policemen should entertain for the District Attorney as a representative of the dignity and sanctity of law. He did not secure liberal patronftfji because possible patrons were de terred by the humane fear of adding to the bttrden of his steeds, and after a few trips the police put I stop to liis activities oing to his lack of a license. Thus this attempt to aeoin modate the public came to a timely end. It failed because It was founded on no proper preparation to meet the reasonable demands of the situation. There Is, however, no good reason why the WlHiamsburc Kridpe should uot be made Immediately useful by a decently equipped stase line. There nre plenty f berata In the city, fully ah to drag an om nibus over the bridge at good speed, with ea for thm themselves nnd with comfort for their passengers. Why Fliould the work be loft to somebody with only scarecrows for motive power It Is not to be supposed for an Instant that the authorities would refuse permission tor the running of proierly equipped stages over the brldjre If a license were sought from them on reasonable terms by trustworthy pers us Some of the automobile rnmnantaa which nre trying to popularize heavy vehicles like truck and stapes might find It profitable to demon strata the capabilities of their inventions by running them on the bridge. If there wero room enough after the cars were running, it might not be a bad thing to have such a line permanently, perhaps allowing Its managers to charge 10 cents fare for extra accommoda tions. That would enable women compelled to cross the bridge at tbe rush hour to enrnpe un pleasant crowding. Comparisons, or contrasts, between Japan and Itusslii are striking, in more than one re epect. Thus Japau has about 47..0U0 people and Russia perhaps 130,.. Again. Japan's land area Is scarcely 13. square miles, while Russia's Is nearly 8,700,. 8o Russia has nearly three times as many people and more than fifty times as much hind as Japan. Wherefore, we might think. Russia might well afford to bo a little less land hungry at Japan's expense. On the other hand, Japnn, with her so much smaller population, has more pupils in her schools than Russia. According to the latest available statistics, Japan has 4.302.G23 chil dren in elementary schools, and Russia only 4.103.594. That Is to say, ninety-one in every thousand Japanese and only thirty-two in every thousand Russians are in elementary schools. The disproportion of numbers in sec ondary schools and universities Is equally marked, In favor of Japan. Again. Japan has 4.80 postofflces. or one to every 9,700 people, while Russia has only 6.029, or one to every 21.500 people. Japan has. under sail and steam, a commercial marine of 734,413 tons, while Russia has only 633.822 tons. Japan's purchases from the United States amount to about 21,, a year, and Rus sia's to only 17,,. Of course. It Is argued that Russia is still in an elemeutary 6ta of development. Rut Russia lias been in full and direct Intercourse with the civilized world 6lnce the time of Peter the Great, two hundred years ago. while Japan has been in a similar state scarcely fifty years. That is to say, Japan has made three times the progress Russia has. and In one-fourth the time. In such circumstances, It Is not at all strange that the admiration and sympathy of the world are given to Japan in a great measure. PISTOLS IN POCKETS. REYES REFUSED AGAIN. Hay Once More Declines to Reopen Panama Question. Washington. Jan. 10. Secretary Hay yester day sent another communication to General Ilafael Reyes, the Colombian Envoy, in response to his protest against the action of the United States regarding affairs on the Isthmus of Pan ama. While State Department officials decline to make any specific statement as to its nature. It is understood that, In a general way, it fol lows the lines laid down In the reply to Oeneral Rwyes's first note, which practically declined to reopen the Panama question, and also follows tho recent message of the President to Congress on the Panama question. Justifying the step taken by the United States government. The reply does not discuss one matter which General Reyes urged In his second note, the transmission to the Senate of the correspondence between himself and the State Department. It is known that the officials of the State Depart ment resented the suggestion of General Reyes as highly improper, and for this reason the an swer does not discuss this request. The matter of sending the correspondence with General Reyes to the Senate has not yet been deter mined by the President. The Bunding of the note to General Reyes yes terday prevented his contemplated trip to Bal timore for treatment by a specialist, for which he had made arrangements the day before. Gen eral Reyes's last note also contained soma ref erence to the submission of disputed points to arbitration, but State Department officials say that there is nothing in the present situation for The Hague tribunal, if any reference to that court were Intended. General Reyes la ready to leave the city at any time for Colombia, where his personal and political Interests require his attention. It was said to-night that he might leave this country within the next ten days, but no information waa obtainable from him, as he declined to see reporters, on the plea that he was very busy. From the standpoint of the State Department, there is no reason why he should hasten his departure, as he might very well remain and render considerable service to his country. Tha suggestion was made to-night that possibly he might stay and try to open diplomatic relations with Panama, through its representative here, for the adjustment of such questions as the as sumption by Panama of a part of the exterior debt of Colombia. Some suggestion also has been made, though not officially, of a reunion of the two govern ments under the name of the Republic of Co lombia, Panama to have an autonomous gov ernment, with absolute authority to deal with all questions relating- to the control of canal matters. An authority c-nversant with Russia's position In the Far East, and her attitude toward American interests, made to-day the following statement In view of the wide circulation given reports without basis In fact, chargins Russia with hos tility to American Interests in the Far East, it seems expedient that the attitude of Russia should be again defined. Russia has repeatedly expressed her Intention of assisting tha development of commercial Inter ests In Manchuria, knowing that the Chinese policy of the United States government Is guided merely by an aim to djvelop tride and not by political ambition. Russia has shown her good faith by refraining from any action which would en danger the eonclu3lon of the American-Chinese commercial treaty signed on October S. That treaty has been ratified by the throne at F and thus, through the medium of tha United States, the important ports of Moukden and Antung. in Manchuria, are opened to the commerce of the world. This is the 'open door which ha been a part of American and Russian policy since the Boxer outrages, which necessitated the Interven tion of the powers, and which materially changed conditions in Manchuria. Russia will certainly not submit to dictaaon at the hands of any power as to the protection of her legitimate Interest in Manchuria. Negotiations ara In progress between St. Petersburg and Peking Ln the effort to reach an agreement adequately pro tecting the special or predominant Inrtuence exer cised by Russia in Manchuria, and which has been recognized by all the powers signatory to the peace protocol verbally or In writing. At tha time ci the signing of that convention It waa Russia's hope that she could with safety with draw her forces from Manchuria last October, and leave the protection ut her interests to China, In 'ho nit time, however, it. was clearly demon strated that the guarantees offered by China were wholly Insufficient, and it became necessary for tr.e Russian government to ask for additional guar antees. Until these have been arranged for tha Russian goernment cannot be expected to with draw from Manchuria, and thus menace the many Russian livea and forfeit the 2.50,A which haa 1.-een spent there in the civilization and development of that province. Russia Is ready and anxious to stimulate the de velopment of foreign commerce in Manchuria. The growth of trade means the success of the Siberian railway. Russia believes, however, that this com mercial development is possiole without the estab lishment of spheres of political influence irx ih open ports. Russia's political influence in this ter ritory, which lies in her borders, is and must 04 considered predominant, and its effectiveness would be lmpairea by the creation of any form of foreign political Influence in the shape of extra-territorial government or municipal control and regulation of certain districts within thaae open ports similar to conditions such as. for example, exist at Shanghai. But no trouble Is anticipated on this score, aj th American-Chinese commercial .treaty, providing for the setting aside of certain districts in Moukcien and Antung -b places of international residence and trade, and the provision for their regulation, is not considered aa tending toward the establishment of a system like that surrounding foreign interests at Shanghai. 'Russia does not propo3 to discuss tha negotia tions now ln progress. B'lt It should be realized that she Is availing herself of very reajonabie means to reach an agreement by diplomacy. It will be an Interesting bit of Information to the Russian government to know that tha primary ol- Ject of the Tokio negot'ations. so far as Japan is corcernpd. Is the protection of American ard Ens- Ush Interests ln the Far East. Russia had supposed that Japan was influenced by less unselfish mo tives. EDUCATION, JUSTICE AND DEMOCRACY. A FOOLISH SCHEME. It is reported that the Assistant Counsel to the Corporation has personally delivered Into safekeeping at Albany a bill which provides for, or permits, the city to Issue ten year bonds wherewith to pay for practically unlimited re pairs to the County Courthouse. The fact that Mr. Guy Is arranging for the introduction of tin iimwiui justices a belief that the admin istration wants to have it passcil and makes a word of warning necessary. Tbcie have been various plans for reconstructing the courthouse at groat expense, and one or two of them have been strongly enough supported to cause some anxiety, but they have not commanded public favor. The must ambitious of these schemes was that propo d by some of the Judges, which called for an outlay of about 2,0X,, and yet was officially acknowledged to be In many respects n tiifftnrr If Mr. Guy's bill should be ptsnd it is not unlikely that an even larger sum would bo demanded. Wo are persuaded that all such ambitious projects nre unwise for two reasons. In the first place, the courthouse is not worth a heavy expenditure. In tho sec ond , if the proposition is virtually to make a new buiUlin of it, though the plans and the Wkmaashlp mi-lit be intrinsically ex cellent, the site would still be unsuitable and the result disappointing. President Ahearn of the Borough of Manhat tan took occasion shortly before he succeeded Mr. Cantor to NMff the proposal that such pcbll- buildings a3 the city urgently needs, in curting a new eonrthocse, should be put up between the Hall of Records and Broadway. Xo such lnrgo plan can be carried out rapidly, but Mr. A hear n Is right in declaring that the city should determine to make an extensive improvement of that nature and do the work gradually as circumstances permit. The first esEPtial 6tp is to take possession of the land. Hi tir opinion, frequently expressed, is that it is foolish to postpone its acquisition. The value of the property will certainly never be less than it is now, and there is every reason to believe That It will steadily Increase. The buildings standing there could bo temporarily used to a greater extent than they now are for the transaction of public business, and from the first ha investment would probably prove avnntageous. Tnerp Is ranch evidence that these views are generally shared by intelligent citizens, as they are knewn to be by members of the present and former administrations, and for this reason Mr. Guy's bill is not likely to find smooth sail ing. Te are convinced that It ought to n ceunter fatal opposition. Undoubtedly, the courthouse is inconvenient and unsanitary. It exposes Juflsros. ELECTRICITY ON THE CENTRAL. Criticism which was elicited by one feature of the electrical programme of the New- York Central Uaiiroad has just received attention from two well known technical periodicals, The Electrical World and Engineer and The Engineering Kecord. Up to tho present time lu-actlailiy all the electric traction work dono m tho world has beea performed with a direct current. A number of experiments have been coodnctod with the alternating current of late. Some of these encourage the hop that this typo of current mny eventually prove serviceable, but it can hardly be siid that all of the minor questions Incident to its adoption have yet beon solved. Under tlie circumstances, tfce Central gave the preference to the direct current, ami now one occasionally hears the suggestion that when its motors are in actual use they will be obsolete. For their approval of the Central's choice tho technical Journals present two cogent reasons. In view of the immense amount of traffic to be handled and the vast Inconvenience which would result from a serious interruption, it Is better to eliminate all doubt and uncertainty at the outset Again, certain other railways notably that In the subway which the Central will make connections have decided to use the direct current. It is desirable, of course, to have the roiling stock so equipped that trains from one road ran be run over the tracks of the other and unnecessary changes of car by pMMBgon averted. To the general public these considerations will appeal so strongly that it Is safe to say that tho Central's decision will ex cite almost unanimous commendation. The pa trons of the road will unquestionably be better pleased to see a well tried system adopted soon than to be obliged to wait several years longer for the promised Innovation. It Is due to tho Central to remember that It has already displayed a distinctly progressive 6plrlt in 6evpral ways. The company Is a pio neer in the substitution of electricity for steam on a large scale In this country. For Its power stations It has ordered engines of the most modern type the steam turbine. The electric locomotives which are to haul Info the city Its great express trains will likewise represent the hitest advances In mechanism which hare stool the test of actual service. Besides, If the time ever comes when the Central deems it expedient to Introduce the alternating current, no orml daWe barrier to the change will exist. No Im portant modification will be necessary In the powr stations. Its dynamos would generate an alternating current anyhow, and the con version of this Into a diroet current would then be discontinued. As for the motors both tho mounted on the trucks of the suburban cars and those employed to draw through trains they could probably be sold without grest loss. Th future, therefore, can be left to take care of itsolf. The present Is of Infinitely greater Im portance. SYMPATHY FOR A DRUyKARD. It wa anything but typical, stern Jersey Jufith'e when a Jury in New-Hrunswlck fined a ririsonor 100 for Inflicting a fatal Injury with a billiard cue In a drunken brawl with a mnn wttla whom bo had been friendly in his sober momenta. It is true the criminal had no Intention of taking the life of his friend. He was so com pletely Intoxicated that he did not know what he was doing. Hut the courts have usually ruled that a man must be held responsible for serious offences against the laws, even when committed under the influence of alcohol. The tine in this en mi a grotesquely insuffi cient penalty fur this homicide. Surely a long term of Imprisonment should have been Im posed, although there was no premeditated and malicious scheme to do mortal harm. Severn lessons In such cases may accomplish good re sults. Maudlin compassion for drunkards who are guilty of crimes while their faculties are befuddled is sorely out of place. ATEItTISO FOREST FIRES. A valuable report on the suppression and pre rratloii of forest fires has jnst been made a li able by publication In pamphlet form. The paper results from action taken last June, after extensive destruction had occurred In tho Adl rnndacks, by the Board of Trade of this city. That organization Instructed Its committee on forests to Investigate tho subject with special retcrenco to New-York State's own preserves, and the duty has been performed in an admi rable manner. No one who read's the document can fail to be Impressed with the clearness, breadth and force with which the matter is handled. In most cases tho only damage done by forest fires Is to the timber itself. Even this amounted to about 3,, In the Adirondack last May, to lay nothing of an expenditure of no, for fighting the flames. A less frequent but more lamentable consequence of these outbreaks Is a loss of life. Five hundred persons perished nt Illnckley, Minn., In 1804 in this way, and about one thousand In Wisconsin In IS7L The fires in New-York State last spring had no such tragic accompaniment, but there are possibili ties which houll not be Ignored. Many thou sand summer visitors go there and to the Cats kills every year. From the North Woods, In particular, the avenues of escape are few, long and tortuous. Had the great conflagration of 1003 occurred throe months later thwn It did, an unprecedented sacrifice of human life mlht have resulted. Still another danger one which has boen less distinctly foreseen, but which should be guarded against is pointed out In tho report nt mentioned. On many of the Bteeper slopes In the Adlrondacks the burning of the old growth hns not been followed by a new one. An Increasing number of unsightly patches is thereby caused. Let that Influence continue to operate, and the mountains will lose their beauty calamity that would be felt by the whole country, and nt merely by a limited lo cality. Denudation might nlso affect the streams which rise in the Adirondack, and on which industry relio for power. Even the question of water supply for remote cities may be more elsely rein ted to the ocenrranee of forest ares than Is irnorally appreciated. A groat deal has been heard of late about the feasibility of llmltrng the effect of tires In the wood 3 by laving out brond parhn. or rides. which intersect one smythpr nt srritable Intervals like city 6trects. The system Is In vogue in Europe, but is only applicable to comparatively level districts. In p. rotten whose surface is so Irregular as that of the Adirondack, thp Board of Trade com ml deems It impracticable. Anothor drawback to the nrioptlon of that plan is that the Staff's ovrn preserves are riot massed in a single area. wrap of them being almost or qultn snrrotinclvd by the property of Individuals or clubs or corporations. There may be parts fit the coMirtry whore the erapoymnit of such lanes would be Judicious, but topographical con siderations discourage their use in Northern New-York. Nevertheless, the committee is able to make four recommndntlons for the promotion of the object in vVmv, and It expresses the hop thnt these will be n.ncttd Into laws. It would have the State's property policed by fire wardens or raacera In the season when fires may bo antici pated compel all camping parties who enter the preserves to employ guides who have been Hocused, and who would know enough to pro vent fires through carelessness Increase tbe penalty for any destruction that Is traceable to railway locomotives, aud provide for State con trol of water' power and water supply. Con cerning the wisdom of the first three of these propositions there will be little dispute. A measure that embodies them should certainly receive favorable consideration at Albany this winter. As to the fourth, ft may be prudent to Isolate it from the others temporarily. Xo doubt such an enactment would assist in preserving the beauty of one of tho mosr famous moun tain jrroups In the world, but it Involves n go.nl mnny other Interests nlso. Tlie committee may be right In protesting agninst giving tho control of the State's water power to nn In dividual or a corporation. In Th Trtbuno ox last Wednesday, was read with considerable interest by the writer. I have noted recently, with a feeling of mild amazement, tntimauona that President Roosevelt la losing his popularity In certain parts of the country that ha a not possibly carry his own State In NoYtracxr that ho la unsafe, because given to Impulsive actions. These criticisms are not conried wholly to those politically opposed to the PreH. dent. But certain Individuals and newspapers of the Republican faith are doing all in tilr power to Increase the perplexity of the average voter respecting the worth of our President. la addition to what I have referred to above they tell us of the part he assumed In the great coal trike. and In the Northern Securities case, dap. recatingly, of course but not a word regard ing ths masterly way he handled the Venezuela problem. To tha mind of many his conduct at that time was proof positive that he coueasa qualities of the highest stateainanap. Ha after the danger point had been passed by ti agreement on the part of the allies to refer tie questions at Issue to the Hague tribunal, there was considerable criticism directed against Ger many for the part that country had taken Ci the affair. In an almost Incredibly short period 0 time the major part of that criticism bad ceased. On looking over certain newspaper clippings of that time I find an item stating that the administration had decided to do all In Its power to check that growing feeling of bitter ness. Wo must admit I was a wise decision, for a great deal of harm can come from tbe un easiness of a great people. For his paQoaoa during the time the allied nations were enforc ing the blockade against Venezuela, and for his farsiehted action after the blockad had been raised, the President should receive duo credit In an Impartial estirnata of his capacity for executive position. As for Mr. Roosevelt's relation to th Northern Securities merger, he would have violated hla oath of office If be na- not taken the action no did. 80 far as I can sea. ha has simply brought that Important case before the Supreme Court for It to decide upon the legality of tbe pro posed consolidation. And again, those who aro free from prejudice may well say that no Presi dent could possibly have assumed a broader minded position In relation to the postal scandal than Mr. Roosevelt has chosen to assume. It I recognized by thoughtful men that dishonesty of public ornctals. If unchecked, will prove 1 most fearful menace to our public institutions Why. things have come to such a pass thai son of our citizens profess to have no faith In the honesty of any man In State or national legis latures. Of course, that Is pessimism run mad. But. on the other band. It Is a straw of some Importance. By the fearless and thorough man ner In which the President has taken hold ef the postal affairs he has performed an act of the greatest Importance to the country. That I another point to the credit of his statesman ship. The wage earners feel that in Mr. Roosevea they have a President who I In sympathy wltA them In their efforts to climb upward. H might listen to the single counsel of ihe great financial Interests If he choe. But he la too great for that. We relieve that he has the Interests of both classes equally at heart. And while the employe class speaks approvingly of the Presi dent, we have also the spectacle of a recent gathering of representative business men en thusiastically Indorsing .him for a renomlnattoa, a striking testimonial of his popularity wlta both classes of men. The srrat basil of business men who conduct their affairs on honest. lawful principles hive no quarrel with the President. On the other hand, one of his strongest claims to our favorable consideration ts the tad that he Is sufficiently alert and brave to block the schemes of a certain class of financiers who have very little consideration for tho welfare or the opinion of the people at large, but ex hibit a great deal of sensitiveness and anxlaty for the success of their own pet plans. I have taken the liberty to write to you staff because I admire President Roosevelt, and see no rmOYi why these who favor him should not be equally outspoken as those who profess to be. opposed to him. On the German Ftfamer Mera, which arrived to-day from southern ports, were M. McManus and C. Thompson, of Halifax, N. S., returning from a search for treasure in Terra del Fueio. They passed tnrcugh exciting experiences, but return without treasure. With eight companions, they sailed from Nova Scotia en March 17 last for Terra del Fuego in a small schooner to loo for treason In kern quantities which Captain Mcleod, of the schooner, said was to be fooad there. The schooner was five months in reaching the Island and in a storm one of the party. Ashley Cooper. was washed overboard and drrwt. ... The vessel finally reached False Cove, Terra del Fuogo, but went aground In trying to land. Then McManut and Thompsoi quarrelled with the other, and. taking their belongings, set out with Indians on an expedition Into the Interior. For several weeks, the two young men lived on shellfish only, and endured great hardships while tramping over the country lot, kins tor elgns of gold. They had to tak turnn Standing guard at night to prevent being murdered by the natives. On striking the coast again they learned ih-.t their companions had got th vessoi off ihe beach and gone to some other place. They then procured a small canoe and m.ide s voyage of 12.. nes by soa, almost to Cape Horn, in a rajn search for treasure that Captain ftfcLieod had said existed there. Jan. 17 Eighteen persons, dele gates to the convention of the National League of Commission Merchants, and their wives, were thrown into the icy water of Echo River, which winds through Mammoth Cave, and were saved only by the coolness of the guide, John Nelson, and the heroic work of Charles A. Muehlbron ner. of Pittsburg. The party included W. J. Harris, of Chicago Mr. and Mrs. O. S. Well, of Cincinnati L. S. Owens, of Chicago Frank K. Wagner, of Chicago John H. Barnett, of Chi cago L.. Lipman, of Chicago Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Smith, of Chicago Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Muehlbronner, of Pittsburgh S. P. Cralsr. of Pittsburg H. C. Rogers, of Buffalo C. S. Stacey. of Minneapolis E. Tubbeslng. of St. Paul Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Fillebrown, of St. Paul, and Miss Lucie Patch,, of Boston. The roof of the cave over Echo River is arched, and the space In the centre, owing to an unaccountable rise in the river, wan only two and a half feet above the water. To Insure the passage of the boat the men an-i women were forced tn sto.ip over. At one place the Iwat swerved to one side, raking the heads of those next to the bank. They leaned further forward to escape striking their heads, and this lowered one end of the boat, causing It to take water rapidly. The guide saw th danger, and called to M Ifnehlbronner to Jump and tak the chain. This he did. landing on a steep, bank, which offered only a slight foothold. Lying down on his face, he held to th chain and pulled the boat toward the bank. The boat .sank m eight feet of water, but further hack, where there was DO landing, the water Is eighteen ft deep. By the light of a single lantern the party escape-i by climbing over Mr. Ifuehlbronner, and, after waiting several hour for a boat, were brought in safety to daylight. SNAG FOR DEMOCRATS. Secretary Cortelyou. of the Department of Commerce and Labor, called on Senator Hanna yesterday on business con nected with the McKinley monument fund and other affairs, and remained for a considerable time In conference with the Ohio Senator. As a result there is considerable speculation in the nlr and rumors of complete harmony In Repub lican ranks are in circulation. No one knows the precise character of the conference between the men named, and definite statements cannot therefore be made nt this time. Senator Hanna has returned from Ohio wear ing the laurels of an almost unprecedented vic tory, and gives every Indication of betas a man well pleased with himself and the world. There appears to be. however, a single cloud on Mr. Hanna'a horizon, and that is what he regards as evidences of intriguing in the party with a view to placing him In a false position. San Domingo, Jan. 13 An incident which came near having serious results, which were averted by the prompt intervention of L'nited States Minister Powell, took place here on the arrival of the Clyde Line steamer New-York. President Morales demanded that the shipping agent surrender the ship' 3 letter, and when the agent refused his arrest was ordered. To avoid arrest the agent went on board the Nw-York. carrying the letters with him. He then sent for Consul Maxwell, who accompanied him to the palace, where President Morales renewed his de mand and compelled the agent to give up sev eral letters. Minister Powell, learning of the incident, promptly went to the palace and demanded that the letters taken from the agent be delivered to him. This President Morales refused to do, but Mr. Powell persisted in his demand, saying that the government had no right tro take such ac tion, and that the President must hand the let ters to him, which President Morales reluctant ly did. Mr. Powell also told President Morales that the agent was entitled tn his protection, as he represented an American company that he Minister Powc-I would not consent to this arbitrary act on the part of the government, and that, further, the agent could not be ex pelled, as was threatened. The case was at last satisfactorily Fettled. Mr. Powell, rinding that the government was unable to protect the tug Anna, which Is owned by Americans, unilt entering San Isidro, re -iiopted the commander of the T'nited States gunboat to guard her. The insurgents threat ened to capture the Anna, ar.'l this morning a strong guard ift the Newport to protect her and other vessels obliged to paa through the waters in that section. fTT. Pphera. The revolutionary General Navarro having seized cattle on an estate at La Fe. which is an American property, the agent of the estate applied to Tatted States Minister Powell for protection. The mtatstet was compelled to refuse the request, as he has no force at his command sufficient to guard the estate. The force on the United States gunboat is too small to safeguard estates from pillagers, and In order to protect United States property thrre is a great need of a larger warship here. If the insurgents should enter the city now it would be impossible to prevent the pillage which would be sure to take place, and there is no other warship here to support the Newport should it be found necessary to land men. TUREK POiyTS IM EAST ASIA. The outlook in East Asia Is undoubtedly more peaceful, or perhaps we should say less war like. There are distinct indications that Rus- sia is Inclined to recede from pome, if not all, of her aggressive demands. That may be be cause the peace party, which is the party of progress and of the Czar, has gained dominance in Russia. It may be because of the all but universal sympathy with Japan expressed by the world. It may be because we have Rus sian authority for saying it of the resolute stand takeu by the United States in behalf of Its treaty rights. It raa be because as we are. now assured from Ber .in France hns grown weary of the one sided Russian alliance and has given Russia to understand that she will have no French aid in case of war, not even though other powers should ally themselves with Japan. Whatever the reason, the fact is patent, and is welcome. There are, however, three remaining points which need to be set tled. One Is suggested ry the Russian Viceroy of the Far East, Admiral Alexieff, through his diplomatic agent, M. I'lareon. in the declara tion that it was unfrieudly and undiplomatic for the United States to make a treaty with j Cnina without Russia's consent, and that Rus sia will not open the ports of Moukden and An- Tuijg. nor permit T'nited States consuls to go thither. That is a point which Admiral AlexleiT and the St. Petersburg government may need to Kettle between them. The course of tho United States is clear. It asks nobody's con sent to its treaty making with another sovereign power. It has made the treaty with China, and It Is 6endlas consuls to the two ports named. It expects that they will be properly receive,, ' and that those ports will be opened aud be kept i open to its commerce. So far as the American ' government pays nttention to Russian utter ances upon this Etibject, it does so to the dec laration of the Czar's accredited representatlvo at Washington, who only last week assured tho Secretary of State that Russia would place no obstacles in the way of our full enjoyment of our treaty rights in Manchuria. We hope and believe that Count Casslnl will prove to hiivo been a more accurate exponent of the Czar's policy than Admiral Alexieff. A second point Is that of foreign settlements in Manchuria, A St. Petersburg dispatch re ports thnt Russia tHI refuses to acquiesce in the treaty rights of foreign power to make set tlements la Mauchuria. though she is, of course, herself making such settlements there without j uumber and of jjreat extent. Japan, we are also told, Is inclined to contest this point, which j is considered vital. Certainly it does seem vital. TJie annulment of the right to make commercial Rettlcments would practically annul or destroy the value of all other rights and ' privileges. What good would it be to us to I iiave the right to trade in Manchuria if our I traders were not permitted to reside in Man- j churian ports Moreover, since Russia Is mnk ing nil the eettlemeuts it pleases her to make in Ifsnrimila. other nations must have the same privilege uuder the most favored nation clanse-a clause which i in ur treaty with China. The third point concerns tho Yalu River. Rus- ' sia Is said to have receded from her pretensions to the control of Corea. even of the northern half of thnt country, and to have admitted that it lies within Japan's sphere of influence. But she still Insists that a eonsidera strip along the northern border of Corea, comprising the Oorean banks of the Yalu and Tiuinen rivers, ' f-hali bo declared a neutral zone, in which Japun 1 make no fortifications or settle ment. But Russia herself already has Bane settlements within It. It does not appear that he hP.s consented ioabandon and withdraw , from them. Moreover. Tho new Governor of Mississippi in his in angural a'.Mress says exactly what was to be expected from him. lie was chosen by the re actionary elements over men who stood for progress and justice to the ne.ro as an expres sion of their bitter spirit toward President Koosevelt because ho recognized the equal rights of negroes .as dtiaena under the law. Governor Vardaman charges that the negro race is as a whole rapidly deteriorating, mid ihat education, instead of preventing crime, pro motes it. lie marshals figures to show that the negroes of the North, who are better educated ihan their Southern fellows, ure also more criminal. He asks for an amendment to the State constitution authorising the legislature to distribute the school fund between the races at it discretion, so as to turn all taxes paM by white persons to white Khoolfl anl keep the negroes in practically entire Illiteracy. This has been a favorite ambition of h's school of pii ticians in several Southern States, but they have so far been signally defeated whenever the issue hns heeii squarely made, and against them are all the most Intelligent white leaders In the South, the oollejre presidents of Southern birth and education and progressive politicians like Governor Ayeock of .North Carolina. Thpe men are as determined as anybody to maintain the supremacy of white civilization in the Booth, but they realize that the only way to solve the race problem is to do justice and help the negro to advance. The South cannot k half its population In barbarism without itself being barbarized. The statements of Governor Vnrdaman about the retrogression of the negroes iiro contra dicted by those of hundreds of unprejudiced ob orver. They are steadily Increasing their wealth, and coming more and more to a realiza tion that there is no short cut to prosperity, but thnt they must follow Booker Washington's fidvice and by hard and honest work nnd good Conduct make themselves respected. Undoubt edly after the abolition of slavery the negro were Impracticable In their aspirations. It was inevitable that they should be. but that they have not made progress, and astonishing prog res, in view of their condition and antecedents, is not true. Perhaps no race starting frntn utter savagery ever advanced faster thnn the negro race in the United States. The statistics of criminal negroes in the North are not fair to the race. The people of this city bv been trented to two Innovations in transportation during tho last few dny. The more Important as well as The more recent of them wns lutroduced v the boroughs of Manhattan and The Bronx. in con formity with a municipal ordinance adopted last year. Surface cars are now required to stop on the near crossing. instead of the fur ther one. to discharge and take on passengers. In defence of the plan it may be urged that it assimilates the practice on ono side of the East River with that which has long boon followed on the other. Inasmuch as a considerable num ber of the people who make use of one set of facilities patroatop the other also, something would be gained by insuring uniformity of habit The chief merit of the system, however is that it minimizes the risk of collision with teams moving through cross streets at right angles with tho street railways. The risk, no doubt has been Increased by the substitution of eee trtctty for cables and horse p, er, beeiiuso higher speeds are vow possible than formerly. All Ihe same, the public inconvenience which attends the new usage will always be so great aa to outweigh these considerations. In line weather it does not matter where the cars stop. When snow, slush or mud prevails, it is litUe Short of an outrage to compel passengers to em bark and alight forty or fifty feet from a cross walk. That ordinance ought to bo repealed promptly, and when such action is takeu the city fathers may well consider the propriety of restoring to Brooklyn the custom observed thero ten or twelve years ago. Another change, made experimentally by the Brooklyn Itnpid Transit Company, affects traffic on the bridge on Sundays. Local trains are then taken off, and an attempt is made to pro vide for those patrons who wish merely to cross the river by carrying them on elevated railway trains. The latter stop tirst at one plat form for through passengers, and then at a second for local passengers, the rear car being reserved for those who expect to leave at the Brooklyn terminal. Uuferttmately, the number of people standing on the ancoud platform in the Manhattan station is often too great to h accommodated in a single coach. Much vexa tion and delay result at the outset, therefore. Still further trouble is experienced on the other side. Only a part of the passengers who there alight from tiie rear probably not over half want to go down to the fltreet. A considera ble number wish to take certain elevated rail way trains nt that point. In order to do so they must follow an unusual route. They are not permitted to .stay ou the platform where they alight until they reach the staircase lead- S-ig upward to the elevated station. They arc required lirst to go down one flight, in order to buy tickets. Thus they Jostle those people who are bound for the street, exhibit excusable un certainty about the proper disposition of their tickets, and drive the rapid transit employes nearly frantic with their questions nnd blun ders. It does not take long to discover a possible remedy for these vexations. If, In accordance with the evident intention of the company, all who want to travel on elevated roads would esahnrk at tho first platform in the Manhattan siatlon, there would probably be plenty of room In the rear car for strictly local passengers, who would have no further cause for complaint. The people who chare these accommodations with them, it is asserted, are aiming for the Ridgewood and U Itpnave, lines. Access to these can be Uad hi two ways. Cue can etart from Manhattan on a Fifth-aye. or Bath Beach train and transfer nt Bridge-st., or he can go across the river with the local passengers v,v transfer at the Brooklyn terminal. Each plan has its drawbacks, a. F.ridge-st. one is lss certain of securing a scat than at High-st., but to make the change at fhe former point takes less rime and trouble than- at the latter. From the behavior f at least a few of those who in sist oa effecting the transfer at the Brooklyn terminal of the bridge, it is apprm m tlj.it they are comparative strangers, and not regular pitnis. Perhaps the others, who have hitherto chosen their route deliberately, may be per suaded to adopt the plan propoeed by the Rapid Transit Company, The experiment may work better after a little further trial. A remarkable tale comes from Oklahoma about village rivalry with tragic results. Snyder nnrt Mountain lark are rival towns three miles apart, separated by a creek. For sonio time Snyder has been luring people away from Mountain Park, the Inilnceinrnts offered being tree lots in tho tormei town an.l the removal of their Mountain Park tons to the new sites free of charge. To facilitate the moving of the houses a bridge was built across the creek. Naturally the relations between the two towns became intense. Thursday afternoon citizens or Mountain Park succeeded In buying the bridge and petting a bill of sale. Then, alter dusk, they want down to the creek with their workmen to destroy the bridge. Citizens of Snyder had learned of the sal and were in ambush on the creek's bank. wait ing for them. The first volley dropped half a dozen of the Mountain Park men. The Snyder men, per haps frightened at what they had done, retreated to their village, pursued by the other crowd with execrations and rifle shots. At latest advices all the able bodied men on either side of the creek were armed to the teeth, and federal deputy marshals were bustling to the assistance of the Sheriff of Ktvwa County in his efforts to command and en force the peace. The most serious accident reported as the result of frozen pipes was the explosion of a small waterback connected with the kitchen stove in the apartments of Mrs Ella Floyd. v No. 112 North Henrj-st. The water r.ad frozen solidly during the night, and when the fire was built the reservoir exploded, wrecking the etove and hurling parts of it all around the room. An ambulance surgeon from St. Cath erine's Hospital dressed the injuries of the family, but did not think it necessary to remove any of them to the hospital. Altbo . rol of most of the fruits of her victory by the intervention of Rus sia, Germany and France, and forbidden to oc cupy the peninsula of Liao-Tung, which would have placed Corea in the centre of Japanese do minion, the island empire did not abandon her ancient . . tion. By means of repeated trea ties and conventions, the Japanese have gradu ally increased their financial and commercial inJiu- nee over the Corean government. Jai in, accordingly, resents Russian Intrusion because of the great amount of Japanese capi tal invested la Corea. At the present time Japan has a practical monopoly in the construction of Corean railroads. Japanese banks have been established throughout the peninsula. The bulk of the carrying trade of Corea is with Japan, and in the year 1902 1,241.43-1 tons of shipping entered Corean ports, of which 39L310 tuxis were Japanese exports. The mo vital reason why the Japanese covet Corea la because this part of the Asiatic conti nent afford. the Bole stepping stone for the con tinental expansion of their empire. It is only fifty miles from the little Japanese Island of Tsu Shima, which ties in th Corean Strait, hall way between Japan and Corea, to the Corean port of Fusan. Russian Siberia occupies th- roast to the north of Corea, Russian Manchuria lies to the east, and the Chinese shore to the southward is being pre-empted by England, Jer many and Italy. An engagement in Somaliland between a British force and the forces of the Mad Mullah has resulted In a revere defeat of the latter, who lust a thousand men killed. The British had two officers killed and nine officers severely wounded. Advanced this morning twelve mie3 to Ji-' balli. First Brigade commanded by Nanning, Second Brigade under Fnskin and mounted troops under Kenna. Total strength of the regu lars, 200 irregulars, 1,. A broken rail two miles west of here wrecked this afternoon the second section of the Erie's Chicago and New- York limited express, eastbound, a solid vest buled Pullman train of five cars. Four cars plunged down a fifteen foot embankment into the Delaware River. The engine and combina tion car kept to the roadbed. ClariESio, colored of Brooklyn, dining oar chef, scalded, back broken W. A. Robinson, col ored, of Brooklyn, second cook. Internal in juries, and John Washington, colored, of New- York, second waiter, internal injuries and left arm broken. Waldorf Policeman Saves Crowd. The running away of a team of Normandy horses, attached to a heavy wagon, in Fifth ave. at Thirty-ninth-st.. at 230 p. m. yester day, resulted in injuries to Superintendent Ma bon of Bellevue and allied hospitals, his two daughters. Patrolman William V. Ryan, of the Broadway Squad David Collins, driver for Dr. Mabon, ar.d Gustavo Woif, a cabman. Five teams were run into and more or less damaged. The runaway horses were caught at Thlrty eecond-st., after passing the Waldorf-Astoria, and almost grazing a number of women and children. The horses were attached to a heavy wagon owned by J. PatehetPfui, a wine dealer, of No. 278 Seventh-aye., and were driven by Augustus Chapius, of No. 124 West Tv.enty-flfth-st. He had left the horses standing in front of a store at Thirty-ninth-st. and Fifth-aye. while he wont in to collect a bill. Something frightened tho animals and they started down Fifth-aye. on the run. As they neared Thirty-fourth-st. the shouts of the spectators warned Patrolman Ryan, of the Broadway Squad, who was on the crossing from the Waldorf across Fifth-aye. A crowd of women and children was on the crossing at the time. Ryan, seeing the horses thundering tow ard tlierri, did not wait for courteous treatment. , t'xr . a cifKfi ajid'uUdre'iitri. -tlirr' the sidewalk. Others he pushed Into snowbanks. All fell in heaps, but none were injured. Ryan, however, was not so fortunate. In trying to get the people out of the way he was struck by the hordes and thrown headlong into a snow pile. Ilia shoulders and one side were Injured, but ho remained on duty. The team was going downhill so fust that the wagon swung from side to side and beat almost a. tattco in striking other vehicles that bad been hurriedly pulled to one side. Many carriage and w sons were struck, an 1 drivers had trouble in quieting their horses. At Thirty-second-st. a phaeton containing superintendent Mabo.n and his two daughters. Rose, twelve, and Margaret, ten yean old. driven by Collins, was unable to get out the runaways' path. The heavy wagon crashed into the phaeton, and all its occupants were thrown to the .street. Collins, the driver, was cut about the head and both hands. Dr. Mabon and his daughters were cut and bruised. They nil started for BetleVTM Hospital for treatment. The runaways swerved to one side and truck a cab driven by Gustave Wolf, of No. ISO Wvst Sventeenth-st. Wolf was thrown from the coachman's seat as if from v. catapult and landed on his head in the snow. He was not seriously injured. The horses by this time, through the many bumping and collisions, had been forced to slow up considerably, and a num ber of people closed In on them and captured them. Would Raise 8,, a Year for CanahThh City Affected. BY TEl,Ei,nni T THE TnJBIXE.I Albany. Jan. 15. Discussion by legislators during the present week of the probable method of taxation which will be employed to raise the money necessary to build the new barge carial has disclosed a rather striking unanimity of opinion that at lenst one measure which the Governor had in his mind at the time he sent his message to the legislature was a record tax on mortgages. The assertion was made at the Capitol this week by a person entirely familiar with the subject of taxation that it was the gen eral impression in Haw-York City among those who had given the matter careful thought that the Governor's plan when it was finally made public would be purely and simply this, the tax being in all probability five mills. Such a tax would raise approximately 3,, annually, the sum which, it will be remembered, the Gov ernor believed sauld be necessary for the first two years. It will he recoiled that in his last message Governor OdJl called the attention of the legis lature to the subject of a mortgage tax, and aid, with what was believed at the time to be of considerable significance Much of the assessment in New-York City is occasioned by taxation upon mortgages, which should not ext. and which Is a positive, burden o ry, ar.tl ii frequent ens tVi5 . Zm per c l ' tJr.ni jli n bn t'r treatment of this class of personal property in its contribution to the expends of government fir would tend to minimize the unjust proportion cf payment of taxes. In two previous messages Governor Odell has dealt with the question of a, mortgage tax. an 1 has recommended the abolition of the direct tax and a one and two mill record tax. He Is known ctill strongly to advocate the abolition of the direct tax. but it is the opinion of those who are best Informed on the subject that the abolition la a matter which requires several years more of education for the public. ThU opinion was expressed only the other day by a New- York City oAetal whose ideas carry weight in this matter. The prevailing notion is that both in his reference In the message and In his two previous recommendations of a more di rect character the Governor foreshadowed the line of action that he believes the legislature should take in raising the 101,.1tO, necessary for the construction of the canal. This new record tax will not affect, it la gen erally believed, any existing mortgages, but sim ply apply to new mortgages. The minimum sum raised annually by such a tax la estimated at dBOQiIi That this may be too low an es timate, and that the Governor has been able to figure a larger income, is also suggested. The burden of this tax, as, indeed, of any tax for the canal, would fall on New-York City, and it has been reasoned that there will be a con siderable effort made to defeat such a measure, although, of course, until the matter la definitely known, no action can even be conjectured. It lv, however, an undoubted fact that it Is along this line that the real estate and financial In terests are looking- for the taxation plan. The question of when this important measure would be Introduced has naturally occasioned more or less guessing. It was said at the Capitol yesterday, with some show of credibility, that whatever measure was Introduced to meet this necessity would not make Its appearance before the middle of February. The only canal interest of present. Importance is the appoint ment by the Governor of the canal commission. The names of this board are expected next week. K. A. Bond, State Engineer, Is generally be lieved to be Elated for a place on this commis sion. DUKE SOUGHT DIVORCE. Philip of Orleans Revoked Petition at Emperor's Request. Vienna, Jan. I.. The Allgemeine Zeitung says that Duke Philip of Orleans is seeking a divorce, and that, he has petitioned the Curia for a dispensation to enable him to marry the daughter of a great Austrian noble. The All gemeine Zeitung asserts that the duke con sulted the leading members of the Royalist party last summer and Informed them of his intentions, giving as a renson that his present union was childless and that he desired to con tinue the royal line. The Royalists endeavored to dissuade the duke from taking the action be proposed, and pointed out to him that his divorce end remarriage would scandalize Cath olic circles in France, the chief supporters of the Royalist cause. Investigation In well Informed circles shows that it was the duke's intention to obtain a divorce from the arebducheaa, but that through the personal intervention of Emperor Francis Josopll the differences of the couple were ad justed, the duke withdrawing his petition to the Curia. The wootaa whom the duke desired to marry is said to be the Princess Clementine, daughter of Pauline, Princess de Metternlch-Sandor. It is said that the strong devotion of the arch duchess to duty is displeasing to the duke. The archduchess has repeatedly tried to induce the duke to live as a more consistent claimant to the throne of France. Duke Louis Philip Robert, head of the Bourbon- Oi leans hiMse. married i- 106 th Archduchess ilirlc Dorothea of Austria. ON DE KALB-AVE., LOOKING TOWARD CENTRAL, AYE. T0 BAR THE DARDANELLES BRITAIN WARNS RUSSIA. Pressure on Porte to 'Allow Black Sea Fleet's Passage. Berlin. Jan. 15. That Russia has applied to Turkey for permission to send her Black Sea fleet through the Dardanelles is confirmed authoritatively here, and it is also asserted that Russia will renew the application and press for Turkish consent. Germany's attitude, un changed from the time the four unarmed Rus sian torpedo boat destroyers passed through the straits in September, 1002, 13 that she has no concern in the matter. The British government Is believed here to have identified itself more fully week by week with the Japanese position, until now Great Britain is almost as deeply committed as Japan. The position In which Great Britain now stands, according to the view taken of the situation here, brought about by public opinion and by the feeling that Russia would yield If only a firm altitude were shown, has impressed and Is Impressing the Russian statesmen. The readiness with which the United States associated herself with Japan In pressing for the signature of the commercial treaties with H ajrei rVlt'ntrinutvii fittif in'fit. Ptersaure that This is not the moment to fight. The decision for war or peace now rests with the Czar's advisers, and symptoms are visi ble here that the decision will be peace, by large ly admitting Japan's demands. The views of the British editors, partially de rived from the Foreign Office in London, are looked upon hero not only as significant, but as part of a great diplomatic game against Russia. The skill Japan has shown through the negotia tions excites admiration at the German Foreign Office. London. Jan. 13. The report published in the United States by a r.ews agency to the effect that the British government had informed Japan that any attempt of tae Russian Black Sea fleet to pass the Dardanelles would be checked by de cisive action is untrue. Lord Lansdowne to-day, however, expressed disbelief that Russia had any intention of trying to send a fleet through the Dardanelles, adding that it would be an ob vious breach of treaty in which Great Britain could not possibly acquiesce. By the Treaty 0 London, signed in 1841 by the five great powers of Europe nnd by Turkey, the Sultan was pledged to maintain the rule of the Ottoman Empire which prohibited the warships of any foreign power from entering the Dardanelles while Turkey was at peace, and, at the same time, the treaty bound the powers to observe this rule. This was confirmed by the Treaty of Paris In 1556 and by the Convention of IS7I. which set forth that tho principle of closing the straits, such as It has been established. Is maintained. At the Berlin Congress on the Eastern question, in 1878. the Russian plenipotentiaries Insisted, in reply to a statement mad by Lord Salisbury, that. In their opinion. the principle of the closing of the straits Is a European principle, and that the exist ing stipulations are binding on all th powers, not only as regards the Sultan, but as regards all the powers signatory to these transactions. The Treaty of Berlin, ratified August 3. ISTS. provided that tho Treaty of Paris of 1556 and the Treaty of London of 1S1 were maintained when not modified by the new treaty, thus continuing the enforcement of the rule. TROOPS ALONG RAILWAY. ML Senator M. A. Hanna said here to-night I have sent out 2. personal letters denying that I am a candidate for the Presidency, and I do not want to be considered as such. I con sider all such talk a 'closed incident. 1 The al leged opposition to the nomination of President Roosevelt has been overestimated and magnified greatly by Democratic papers and others with Democratic proclivities. Senator Hanna said that he would issue the call for the Republican National Convention in a few days. It had been delayed on account of the talk about Chicago hotel keepers advanc ing their rates. THE CONVENTION CALL. Hanna Friends Express Indigna tion at Rumors of Treachery. WOll THE TKIBVXB BrsSAU. 1 Washington, Jan. lo. Friends of Senator Hanna in Washington. Including Senator Scott, Of West Virginia, profess indignation thru thy I rumor of underhand dealing on the si rj a he .- . r..x tp iui,-'-.' c ...-. t . oltniU these aiapatcii'Vu.it r.h. .-pol1 have been made public. Thy assert that Sena tor Hanna Is too hlghminded a politician and too , fair a fighter to permit of his doing anything underhanded, and declare that there is no studied attempt to withhold the call for the national convention. They also add numerous excuses for the delay In calling the convention, reciting Mr. Hanna's ill health and Mr. Heath's press of business matters. Those leaders whose devotion to the President is unquestioned are disposed to accept the ex cuses in good part, and express gratification that the postponement of the call is not the re sult of any studied attempt, frankly admitting that they were disappointed that the national chairman did no find it convenient to come to Washington and issue the call as soon as his re-election to the Senate had taken place, in stead of returning to Cleveland, but they feel certain that, now the attention of the Senator from Ohio has been called to the importance of prompt action, he will permit no further delay. With regard to the publication of the report, which was in general circulation at the Capitol yesterday. It is believed that its effect cannot but prove beneficial. It is but one of several rumors, similar in their import, which have been in circulation in the last two weeks, and its publication has afforded the friends of Senator Hanna an opportunity to explain the delay and deny any purpose of inconveniencing the friends of the President. It has further served to make plain the desire of those Republicans who have the best Interests of the administration at heart to hold early conventions. Senator Hanna is expected in Washington at an early date. pOF3ibly to-morrow, and will, it is believed, immediately issue the call for the national convention. It is regarded as desira ble that all doubt as to the unity of the party in its support of the President be promptly .Im pelled, and the calling of the State conventions and the relection of delegates to the national meeting will do much to dispel any lurking doubt which may exist. As a matter of fact. Senator Penro.se has felt it desirable to issue the cull for the Pennsylvania convention without waiting for the national call, and has to-.ay sent out the notices which were prepared yester day and held up only because of the ruiror pub lished In The Tribune this morning. Mr. Pen rose is still in Philadelphia, presumably con ferring with Senator Quay, but he telegraphed to Colonel Andrews to-. lay to issue the State call. A thorough search of the history of the Re publican conventions has proved that the ex ecutive committee could find no justification for attempting to enforce the unit rule by the framing of its call. In the national convention MM a resolution, offered by Mr. Boutwell, of Massachusetts, and amended by Mr. Butter worth, of Ohio, was adopted, providing. In part, that such methods or rules shall Include or secure to the several Congress districts in the United States the right to elect their own delegates to the national convention. Thi3, the amendment of Mr. Butterworth, was adepted only after a fierce contest, as its adoption re sulted .in the defeat of the third term candidacy of President Grant. Since that time there Baa been no action which could astj be con sSfued as relieving the party from thf aMlsjejasj cf that rule. It is. further pointed out that at the last meeting of the Republican National Committee a resolution was adopted instructing that the form of the call of 1900 b used In calling the convention of this year, and that, in Itself. would prevent any attempt materially to change it. These facts have been called to the atten tion of the doubters, and they express their willingness to abandon their former belief as to the occasion of the delay in the issue of the national call, but it Is evident thai they will feel relieved when the call .- actually issued. U. S. SAILORS UNDER ARMS Convoy for Trig at San Domingo Sharp Fighting. San Domlnpo. Jan. '.'.. Th.- tug An, the prop erty of an estate at San Isidro, was prevented by the insurgents from reaching the estate, and the owner applied for protection to Minister Powell. The latter Informed the government officials that If they could not protect the Ana he would. Commander Herts of the United States gun boat Newport furnished an armed convoy for the Ana, equipped with a field gun. The two boats were ready to leave port when the srov ernment endeavored to prevent their departure. Minister Powell promptly directed that the boats should proceed, and said that he and Com mander Mertz would accept all responsibility for their action. Later Minister PoweO and Commander Mertz waited upon the President and told him that if his government could not protect American property the Newport could and would. Th Ana carried 2 1., which the Insurgents hoped to capture. There was a severe attack on the city this evening, bur the troops managed to repulse the Insurcenta. The gunboat inUeindencia arrived here last night with two irtured Dominican schooners In tow. The si hookers carried arms and muni tions of war intended for coast defence. This morning the Independence bombarded the suburbs of the city, with the object of driv ing the revolutionists out. It is officially reported that Ban and San Cristobal have been retaken by the govern ment troops. There rap a severe encounter between the government troops and the insurgents at HaJna. with a result favorable to the government. The government has issued a decree closing the ports of Azua de Compostela, San Pedro de Macorlf. Samana, Sanchez, Puerto Plata and Monte Cristi, to take effect within twenty days. in the cafe of vessels coining from the Antilles, within thirty days for vessels from American ports and within forty-five days for vessels from European ports. Armed schoners and gun bouts will guard the closed ports. Commerce is completely at a standstill. News from the interior cannot be obtained. nOVFTRNOR ODELL. Taken at Albany yesterday by a Tribtni photographer. THE RECENT FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENTS. An exceptionally large number of railroad accidents, with many fatalities, have occurred since the beginning of December. The following list shows the casualties Dec. 2. A collision of two freight train at Greenwood, Del., causad the explosion of a tank car of naphtha, killing two person and injuring many, besides causing a conflagration which destroyed both trains and ai entire block of building. Dec. 13. Five men were killed and three severely injured on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad near Piedmont. W. Five persons were killed and ten injured in a collision on a bridge on the Chicago, Burlmgtcn and Qyincy read near Albic. vv--. Dec. 21. Nine persons were killed anc thirty to injurec. in a wreck en the St. Luis and San Francisco Railway at Godfrey, Kan., caused by a fast train, in trying to make up time, running into in open switch. Dec. 24. In s wreck on the Baltimore and Ohio Riilroad near ConnellsviUe, Perm., seventy-six persons were killed and nine hurt. The train wrecked was the Duauesne Limited, from Chicago to New -York, running at a hinh speed, and it was thrown from the track by heavy timbers which had fallen on the track from a freight train going in the opposite direction on tho other track around a curve a few minutes before. Dec. 26. Twenty-two lives were lost n a head-on collision between two passenger trains on the Pere Marquette Railroad, near Paris. Mich. The accident was attrib uted to the blowing out by the wind of a red signal lantern. Besides the dead, there were twenty-nine person injured. Dec. 31. Three trainmen were killed in a railroad wreck near Ashtabula, Ohio, caused by an open switch. A fireman was killed at Newburg by a locomotive leaving the track in the deep snow. PARKER WIGWAM CHOICE MCARREN FOR CHAIRMAN. Murphy and Senator to Make Known Tammany's Wishes in Washington. Charles F. Murphy and Senator Patrick H. McCarren will. It was said laet night by one of their intimate friends In Tammany Hall, tell the Democratic National Committee in Washington nexi Tuesday that New -York State is solidly for ihe nomination of Chief Judge Alton B. Parker of the Court of Appeaia, for President. Senator McCarren will start for Washington on Sunday night. Mr. Murphy, according to the Present understanding, will see Chairman Jones and the other members of the committee on Sun day night Mr. Murphy Is expected in New- York on Monday. He left town on Tuesday niffht for Annsipolls. Washington and Atlantic City. If Meaara. Murphy and McCarren find the drift In the National Committee toward Parker. It is likely that Norman K. Mack, of Buffalo, will resign as the New-York member of the committee and be succeeded by Senator McCarren. and should the National Convention nominate Judge Parker. Senator McCarren will be chosen by him as chairman of the National Committee. It is not expected that Mr. Murphy, so far in advance of the meeting of the National Con vention, will make an open announcement that the .New- York State delegation will be for Judge Parker. In order to make the drift toward the judge oiill more marked, it will only be neces sary for Messrs. Murphy and McCarren to tell the members of the National Committee that every one In New-York want- Parker. There Feems to be a general sentiment in favor of a New- York man for the head of the ticket, and the Southern Senators seem to show a marked preference for Judge Parker. The race at the present time among Demo crats here seems to have narrowed to two men- Parker and Gorman. Senator Gorman's Intense racial prejudices, on which he made a winning campaign for his Benatorship, has put him at a great disadvantage with Judge Parker In the Northern States, according to Mr. Murphy's friends, and for that reason he Is a poor second at this time. A Russian Legation guard of thirty men has been landed at Chemulpo, hut the Japanese railway has refused to transport it to Seoul. The St. Petersburg correspond ent of the Paris edition of 'The New-York Her ald send the following dispatch There is almost no hope of a peaceful solu tion, and the public is expecting news of a battle resulting from the landing of Japanese troops in Corea. A battalion has been sent from Vladi vostok to prevent the Japanese landing. There is no doubt that the Russian reply in timates in a friendly way that Russia cannot accept Japanese interference. The Russian government has approached the Wilson Line, asking what ships of the lin could be chartered in the Back Sea. RUSSIAN REPLY SEA RET. Delivered in Tokio Negotiations Not Yet Abandoned. Tokio, Jan. 6 lt is believed here that the Russian response has been handed to the gov ernment, but the secret oi its delivery has ben Jealously guarded, and the nature of the reply remains undisclosed. The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Baron Ko mura, called this afternoon upon Baron de Rosen, the Russian Minister to Japan, with whom he remained an hour, and later he vis ited Premier Katsura. with whom he held a long conference. There Is every indication now that further negotiations will take place, although it Is ex pected that Japan will refuse to transfer the discussion of affairs to St. Petersburg, If this is proposed. Japanese Emperor Discusses Situ ation rcitk Governor Taft. Toklo, Jan. 6. Oovernor Taft of the Philippine Islands and Mrs. Taft were received in audi ence by the Emperor and Empress, and were Kiists at luncheon at the palace later. An Informal discussion took place, the Em peror expressing his satisfaction at the friendly relations which exist between America and Japan, which he hoped would continue. He wished the Americans to understand that Japan was striving earnestly and patiently to main tain peace. BRITAIN MAY INTERVENE. Cabinet Meeting Called Men to Manage Japan's Warships. London. Mr. Balfour. and other ministers, having arranged for a fortnight's absence from London. The railroad station was crowded with sightseers, who showed great enthusiasm. There were repeated cheers for the gallant little Jars. THE XEGOTIA TIOXS. Japanese Statement of Points at Issue in Far East. Tokio, Jan. 6. A high Japanese authority to day made the following explanation of the status of the Far Eastern questiors The statement that Russia has made conces sions to Japan is not exact. On the contrary. Russia in the month of October made certain concessions, which were accepted by Japan, but subsequently withdrew them and assumed an attitude which left the Japanese little hope in the way of reaching a satisfactory agreement. The Japanese government, confident in the declarations of disinterestedness in Manchuria made by Russia, and recognizing Russia's spe cial interests in that region, wished to regulate, once for all, all questions in the Far East, in the interest of future peace and tranquillity. To this end Japan made the following proposals First Russia, and Japan should mutually respect the Independence and territorial integrity of China, and Corea. Second recognise reciprocally. Japan the- spe cial interests of Russia in Manchuria Russia, the special interests of Japan in Corea. Third enae mutually not to Infringe. Japan the commercial rights and immunities acquired by Russia in Corea Russia, the commercial rights and Immunities acquired by Japan in Manchuria. In making the third proposition Japan wished not only to protect her own rights in China and those of Russia in Corea, but to consecrate by the principle of equality of treatment the com mercial rights of all nations in Corea and China. Russia declined the Japanese propositions and submitted a counter proposition, which con tained a clause providing for the creation of a neutral zone extending trom the Chlnese-Corean frontier to Wong-Tan, on the east and to Ping Yang on the west. This zone comprised almost a third of Corea.
