Silver has been so long in use that no other money, except gold, is known, the Ignorance of any other being so extensive that among the natives Amer ican nickels and coppers are refused when offered. The officials all realise that II will be a long and tedious task to educate the people to understand thai a paper currency, secured by a public deposit i gold i.s worth its face value. To overcome this national prejudice against paper will be the great est difficulty in the way of acceptance of the plan. yr the Panamans ar counting with absolute con naenoa upon the ratification of the canal treaty ami the early payment to them of the ..-- In American gold. This matter of converting the currency system from a depreciated and varying silver basis to the gold standard is. however, the smaller horn of the financial dilemma confronting Panama. Under the old regime the revenues for thia department are supposed to have aggregated about 1500. annually ibis amount may not be exact, at the statistics are very faulty. Half a million la given, however. us a safe estimate for purposes of calculation These revenues are derived from several sources, and were supposed to be of two classes- one for th national and the other for the departmental ex chequer. Colombia managed very successfully to gobble all of it. but the nctlonary division is still used In the bookkeeping. The national share earns from an import tax on alcoholic liquors, from a nominal tax on real estate, and from the- sale of certain of the concessions that have proved such a bane to the isthmus. The departmental revenues were variously derived from a tax on the produc tion of alcoholic liquors, from a nominal license assessed against saloons, and from the sale of certain other concessions. The amount named und the sources from which It was derived do not Include the sum of 250.066 gold annually paid by the canal company for its concession. of this amount ' 5. gold was supposed to go to the Department of Panama, although the whole sum was always taken by the government of Bogota. Upon this amount It Is useless to figure, as during on i of her bankrupt moments, many years ago, Colombia went to the usurers and discounted th.s icesm fee for a ten of years which will not expire until nine years hence so that until ulz Panama cannot count upon receiving any revenue from the canal concession by way of rental pay ments. THE REVENUES MUST SHRINK. Thin Introduces the most serious difficulty before Urn new republic. By the terms of the treaty with Panama the United States does not begin to pay the KSO.OSO annual rental for the canal aon until th year 1913. Under the same agreement Colon and Panama, tha only ports at which there la any custom hou business of consequence, are mad. to al tents and purposes, tree for th entry of merchandise of all classes. Now. Befior Amador, Minister of Finance who was departmental treasurer during the Colombian dominion, estimates that threM-fifthfi, or 1900. of all the revenues, national and departmental, were derived from the customs duties. This sum will by the provisions of the treaty with th United States. exists to bo collected, and the revenues of the new republic will, In consequence, be cut down to ... thing like 1300. sliver annually. Figure us they will and they are, figuring hard and very closely the officials of the new republic cannot discover how it will be possible for them to conduct the government or. a sum under 5- silver a year. To bring the expenses within that sum the army U to be reduced to mere nothing ness the navy li to b permitted to lapse Into an almost visionary state, and oth.-lai salaries ar to be fixed at tii- lowest limit conslHtent with good service and th preservation of satisfaction and contentment In nttlt al circles. With ail of this Panama looks a deficit of about 53U0. a year squarely In the face. Under these circumstances. It la not difficult to understand the desperation of her Immediate financial prospects The situation may be eased slightly by Increasing UM tax on Halooni and on the production of iilcohollo liquors, and by more rigid enforceme. t of the law in such respects, though It is impossible to hope fir much from this source. Th saloons here are h.i poverty stricken as arf the people while the only liquors produced are what i 9 known as chics, the native , and a native whlta rum. fairly good In quality, but by force of ctr ciMiiHtHncea small In quantity and marketed at an extremely low figure. The Imposition of a tax on personal property would avail nothing, as, asld from a very few people, the Panamans have no property worth assessing nor Is It possible to add very much to the revenues by Increasing th tax on real estate, for to tax It much heavier than at prent would be to tax It out of the hands of It owners. After explaining all of these facts and producing ample proofs for their statements, the official of th government will very frankly admit that they art In a quandary. It would be Impossible, of ooursi, for them to pay expenses out of th prin cipal payment for the. canal concessions until th payment of the annual rental enriches the puhlla treasury but thl they are loath to do. They are too long headed In a business way to deplete the only a.set they have, or are ever likely to have. It would, too, be possible for them to float a loan after tho establishment of the regular government but that Idea la not looked upon with favor for a loan would only Increase th annual charge against the government, and sooner or later tho principal would have to be paid. To relieve her condition and extricate herself from this financial dilemma It la absolutely neces sary for Panama to have JiOOft,to. or thereabouts of the canal concession fee put out at Interest. It Is her only hope. This sum. If placed at 4 per cent, would, even after the republic goes to a gold basis, afford It revenues ample for all t legiti mate requirements. The Investment must be with th United States end so secured by convention that the principal carl never be. levied upon by the republic. Just now the United States Is In the highest favor on the Isthmus. It would materially Increase the respect In which she Is held, besides strengthening her con trol and easing her solution of the police and other problems appertaining to dominion over tha canal lone, If she should meet Panama half way in this matter. By making herself the custodian of ejght tnnths of the canal concession fee she would ease the financial strain upon the new republic, and, while keeping S,mi In her pocket, Incur no obligation except for the annual payment of a reasonable interest. The Weather Bureau said it wasn't a bliz zard in the strict, technical sense of the term,' but the public in general, not being a sCa.Maw for the etiquette surrounding polito weather expressions, called it a blizzard. Six inches of snow underfoot, a sky full overhead, a tempera ture of 10 degrees above zero and the -wind Mowinsr thirty-four miiea au hour were suffi cient to justify the expression. Commuter who stamped on ferryboat decks as the pilots felt their way cautiously in tha harbor, peopl on trains that were anywhere from one to two hours late, as were those on almost every railroad running into the city, peugers in blocked and snail-paced surface cars, team sters r.-ho tried to hold up slipping. steaminaT horses, pedestrians who slipped and atumbls and measured their lengths en the sliiewsJk these told one another it was a blizzard. Early in the morning the snow began fanirur ani the wind rising, and as the hours advanced the snowrlakes srrew larger and cn down faster, and the wind, not to be outdone, waxaU stronger with each gust. The light of a gray day dawned on a perfect blizzard aetting Long lines of deformed, hunchbacked peonl ploughed the smooth surface of the snow ht into myriad tracks, as they waaded their way to the elevated stations. With ths beglnnlnT of trafflc began the trials of man and teast. Panting horses, struggling In vain, went down by ths hundreds. Some lay in the snow untn a bullet ended their sufferings. Others. wttb the aid of blankets and cuss words, scrai bled to their feet and again essayed to haul their heavy loads. Men and women, too, found preserving balance and foothold a difficult task, and many was the liniment bottle laat nlgbs. that made frequent trips to the drug store. As the day wore on the temperature dropped steadily, and surface trafflc began to feel the clogs on its wheel. All to Quit if Power House Men, Non-Union, Work. Another subway tieup Is threatened unless by noon to-day non-union men employed by firms outside of New-York to put In the equip ment at the West Flfty-nlnth-st. power house of the company are discharged. There are five or six of these firms, the largest of which Is the Alis-Chalmer3 company, of Cleveland, which fought the last general strike of the Interna tional Association of Machinists throughout the country for the rine-hour workday for over a year. Since then It has employed non-union mn. There has been a great deal of feellnj among the unions of BkilleJ trades for some time at this power house over the employment of these non-union men. It culminate,, it was stated yesterday, by the unions in nearly a dozen skilled trades whose members are employed at the power house informing the com raptors for the subway who employed their members that If the non-union men were not discharged before noon to-day work rt the power house would he tied up and the strike extended to all the subway. Previous to this there was a strike by fifty union tile layers employed by the Manhattan Glass Tile Company in the subway station at Elghteenth-st. and Fourth-aye. against the em ployment of four non-union men. President S. B. Dcwsnap Of the company said that tha strike was a. violation of the arbitration agree ment of the Building Trades Employers' Asso ciation, of which the company Is a member, end which the Tile Layers' Union had signed. At the Building Trades Club it was stated that M Milken Brothers are the only members of the Employers' Association who are doing work .t the Fifty-ninth-st. power house, where they em ploy members of the new housesmiths' organi zation. It was stated on behalf of th firm that It expected its employes to observe the arbi tration agreement and refrain from striking. Word of the ultimatum of the skilled trades to-day reached the Building Trades Club, but no ore would discuss it. A good deal of the work along the subway is completed, and altogether the strike programme. if it is carried on, will involve about three thousand men. The contractors are In a hurry to get the subway completed, and any delay, however short. Is looked on as a serious thing at present. The strike would be a violation of the agreement between the Central Federated Union and the Rapid Transit Contractors' Asso ciation. By this agreement, before anything else is done, all differences and disputes are referred to a Joint arbitration board of subway contrac tors and the Central Federated Union Rapid Transit Committee, of which John J. Pallas is president until his successor is appointed. John 13. McDonald, general contractor for tho subway, said that -no complaints had been made to him, and he had not been oclally informed of any Impending trouble. President Dewsnap of the Manhattan Glass Tile Company said the four iron union men were specialists, who showed the tile layers how to use a patent cement the company adopted. Ho granted all other demands, and explained to William H. Farley, business agent of the tile layers before the strike, that these men had no union. At the last meeting of the arbitration board of the Employers' Association, which Farley attended, he failed to mention this strike. A CUBAN TARIFF DILL. House Passes Measure to Allow Palma to Increase Duties. Havana, Jan. 13. The House disposed of the tariff question to-day by passing a bill au thorizes President Palma to Increase duties in his Judgment, not to exceed 30 per cent more than the present rates. It is believed that the Senate will approve this bill. The House in secret cession also considered the Senate's proposition for paying the revolu tionary bonds, and practically decided not to ap prove it unless the Senate should approve the proposition of the House to sell public lands at auction and apply the proceeds to the payment of the revolutionary' soldiers. The Cabinet this evening ordered the sale at auction of tho Jucaro-Morcn Military Railroad, which runs along the line of the Puerto Principe trocha. Tne employes had assembled at tho close of work In the corridors on the different floors, waiting for the elevator to take tnem down. The pate gave wuy just as the elevator started to descend. James Johnson, the elevator operator, was taken into custody by the poiice. pending an hnreatlga tton. TOO FUDDLED TO TRY CASK BECHTEL TRIALS HALTED. Judge Stops District Attorney The Second Acquittal. BT TEI-CGRAPn TO TIIE TRIBUNE. Allf-ntown, Perm.. Jan. 13. Owing to the condition of District Attorney E. J. LJchtenwalner. thero was an abrupt adjournment this afternoon in the Bechtel murder trial after Alois Eckstein, one of the suitors of the murdered girl, had been acquitted of complicity in the crime. L.lchtenwalner was so befuddled that it was with difficulty tnat the case was carried to a conclusion, and the shabby old courtroom was the scene of the. wellntgh un precedented spectacle of a District Attorney, after hearing his own witnesses and calling several of those originally putrmonfd by the other side, ask ing for a verdict of not guilty. In the words of Judge Trexler from me bench, the prosecuting at torney had succeeded in establishing an alibi for the defence. Several times the court interfered and threatened to end the proceedings for the day unless the Commonwealth conducted its case in a more order ly manner. At one time the District Attorney's assistant took charge, only to be set aside by his Chief later. The proceedings were endured until after the Jury had been Instructed to render a ver dict of acquittal, when Judge Trexler adjourned the court. The cause of the trouble wa unfortunately pat ent enough when court convened after the noon recess. Mr Lichtcr.walner had returned to court in a condition Which It Is kindest to believe was the result of Ffim.' natural indisposition, and from that moment his com went pieces. His voice was thick, and his manner abstracted. Ho would sem to fortcet asking a question, and would repeat It to weariness. His queries were atsurd. and at last his inability properly to manage matters be cam so painfully apparent that Judge Trexler declared If the Commonwealth does not con duct it case in an orderly manner I shall adourn court until to-morrow. The District Attorney wanted to go ahead with the trial of the accused members of the Bechtel family, but. tb attorney for tin BechteU pro. tested emphatically. The District Attorney, how ever, was insistent, and ordered the names of the defendants called, but the Judge interrupted, say- Ing to the District Attorney I- you Intend to conduct the prosecution your self or will ou rely on assistant counsel If the latter, the trial will ko on, otherwise th court will adjourn until to-awrrow morning. The District Attorney proposes to conduct this cao himself, Llehtenwalner was understood to reply. Then thin court stands adjourned until 9 o'clock to-morrow morning, ordered the Jodfa, Before court opened to-day the District Attorney admitted that h had a weak case against Eck stein, and did not expert to convict hire. His hope was that something might develop in the examina tion that would lead to a clew to the real murderer or murderers. Tho opening address of Mr. Lutz, who is assisting thn District Attorney, was exceed ingly brief, and did not indicate that the Common wealth expected to fasten complicity in th mur der on Eckstein. Eight witnesses were called, but the only point brought out was that Eckstein and the girl frequently quarrelled, and that Eckstein Is alleged to have said to her You are trying to drive me to the grave, but you may get there before me. This testimony was given by Mrs. Brobst. the dead girl's clutor. who said that she overheard the remark about Easter last year. David Welnenberger, who was acquitted yester day of complicity In the crime, refused to answer many questions put to him with reference to ins re lations with tho cirl. The examination of the last two witnesses called was prolonged beyond all reasonable time. In fact, at one time It looked aw though the District Attor ney wns tryinK the CAM for the defence, und Judge Trexler interrupted him. saying 'Are you trying to establish un alibi for the de fondunt Finally the District Attorney announced that tho Commonwealth had no more witnesses to examine, and was therefor- compelled to ask that the de fendant be discharged. Judge Trexler Instructed the Jury accordingly, and, without leaving their seats, they rendered a verdict of not guilty. The attempt to continue the cases and the ad journment of the court in consequence of the Dis trict Attorney's action followed. STRIKE ON STEEL TRUST. Coal Miners Ordered Out Cut in Pay the Cause. Resolutions ordering a strike in the coal mines of the United States Steel Corporation In the Leesburg district, But ler County, were adopted to-day at the conven tion of the Pittsburg Division of the United Mine Workers of America. The reduction, he says, will greatly af fect the annual conference to be held in Ind ianapolis in February. ARBITRATION IN FAR EAST TRIBUNES SUGGESTION. Public Opinion in France Favors Such a Solution. Social to The New-York Tribune by Frasb Cable. Copyright. 19o4 By The Tribune Association. Paris, Jan. 13. The suggestion of The New- York Tribune to refer the Ru3so-Jap' sst WaV culty to the Hague Tribunal has been widely re produced. In the Temps. the Journal dcs Dbats. the Libert, the Matin. the Fi gar. the Gau'.Ms. Gil Bias. the Journal. the Petit Jourr-il and in the leading papers of the departments the idea, on the whole, comes as a welcome solution in the present pacific tendency of th Gallic spirit, for everywhere, except among a few redhot Nationalists, any notion of France being drawn into active intervention is dreaded as an awful calamity. Nevertheless, moderate patriotic organs, such a the Temps and the Journal dcs Debnta refrain from urg ing France's great and beloved ally, the Emperor of Russia, to take the initiative, and The Trib une's suggestion, is published without comment. The true gist of French opinion is set forth in the conversation I had to-day with the French apostle of arbitration and the French delegate to th Hague Tribunal, Baron d'Estournelles de Constant. Deputy of the Sarthe, who made the following statement We must not expect too much from the Hague Court. Its creation is still recent, and yet last year and the year before all the European pow ers, France included, were more or less hostile lo the court and tried to boycott it. It Is only the prudent initiative of the United States that has saved the Hague Court from that tacit hostile coalition, but President Roosevelt, in do ing so when ha sent before the court the case of the Pious Fund of California, took great care to choose that case among the small and merely financial foreign difficulties of his government. He would never have begun with a big polittcal affair, and if another government had advised him to follow a different line he would have certainly refused to li.-ten to it. It is the same with Russia. . for Russia un doubtedly considers her difference with Japan a3 a national one. and that is why I think it would be useless to advise her to brlJr.K it before th Hague Court, but if Russia is. not prepared to go to The Hasrue she cannot forget the Hague Convention, which may give to her, as well as to Japan, important facilities, for the settlement of their conflict. For instar - e. it has been de cided by Article thav every civilized power is morally bound to offer her bons offices. Very likely England has already offered her bons of fices to Japan, and it may be that France, In accordance with the universal pacific feeling of opinion, has tendered the same to her ally. Rus sia. I am afraid nothing more can be done now. Let us lgin, as President Roosevelt has done, with small cases. As fur the great questions, let us try to settle them with th resources of the bons offices. Adrier. Hobmrl. E.litorof the Temps. when consulted on the subject, declined to express an opinion, considering the matter, In view of the French alliance with Russia, too delicate for France to take the initiative In such a proposal. M. Perivler. Editor of Cril Bias, approved generally The Tribune's suggestion, but ex pressed confidence that war would be averted. and deprecated the manoeuvres of Stock Ex change speculators, who seemed to be using all their efforts to precipitate a conflict. Senator Saint-Germain, when asked for hi 3 views on the subject, said It would be a splendid thins if the Hague Tribunal should give a pacific solution of the Russo-Japanese difference. The Emperor of Russia has astinied the title of Emperor of Peace, and utilizing the Hagne Tribunal would be an excellent opportunity to Justify such a title. If Nicholas II would only manifest a de sire to refer the dispute to The Hague Japan would be compelled to submit to such arbitra tion, and this would terminate the matter peace fully. Otherwise the dispute may have far reaching consequences. Firm confidence prevails here that the dis pute betwee.i Russia and Japan will be settled amicably by giving Japan predominance in Corea and by Russia observing the. open door treaties In Manchuria. C. I. B. RUSSIA'S TURN TO REPLY. Japan's Response Made Xo Time Limit Set for Answer. London, Jan. 13. A dispatch from Tokio to Reuters Telegram Company says that Japan's answer to the last Russian note was handed this afternoon to Baron de Rosen, the Russian Mins ter, and that negotiations will be continued without any time limit being setifor their ter mination. It is stated In Toklo that Japan has never asked for the evacuation of Manchuria, but frankly recognizes Russia's special Interests there and her right to protect' them. Japan only demanded the realization of Russia's voluntary pledges respecting China's territorial Integrity in Manchuria and the freedom of residential rights and international trade there. Another dispatch from Toklo says the min isters who attended the recent conferences for the consideration of the reply to the Russian note assert that the attitude. Japan ha 3 taken is remarkably conciliatory. The Foreign Office state 3 that it has not re ceived the slightest Intimation regarding Japan's course in connection with the last Russian note. The Japanese Minister. Baron Hayaahi Am bassador Choate, and Count Berr.storff, the first secretary of the German Embassy, -ere among the callers at Lord Lansdowne's reception to day. The leading feature of the debate In the Senate to-day was the speech on Panama made by Senator Depew, who spoke to crowded galleries and a well tilled chamber. Although Mr. Depew had given notice of his In tention of addressing himself to the Panama question to-day, he cams near being crowded out by Senator Spooner. Mr. Spooner. who peaks extemporaneously, and. as a rule, only when be becomes so charged with Ideas that he can no longer contain himself, arose to reply briefly to certain animadversions of Mr. New lands, who had spoken earlier In the day. In tending to speak only a moment. Mr. Spooner quickly -warmed to his subject, while Senator Depew politely waited for him to conclude his remarks. When It became obvious that the Sens tor from Wisconsin was petting well under way for a speech of several hours, a note was ent to him by Senator Aldrlch. calling his at tention to the fact that Mr. Depew was sched uled for a epeecft. In a moment more another not came from Senator Allison, and then fol lowed several other, and the eloquent Wis consin Senator gradually put on the brakes and eventually subsided, after which Mr. Depew toured the floor. Mr. Depew said that the opponents of the treaty are aiding the enemies of the canaL It. he continued, there ha been a concert of ac tion among any great railway corporations to defeat this most beneficent work of commerce and civilization. I am not aware of it, but if such a combination does exist, then its allies and ft most efficient assistant are to be found among Chose who. under any device or excuse, are endeavoring to defeat the treaty with th Republic of Panama. He went into details concerning the Hay-Her ran treaty, declaring that President Marroquin of Colombia had the Colombian Congress In his power and dictated the course pursued by It, with the end in view of securing better finan cial terms from the United States at the ex- Ik pease of the canal company. He charged Marro m null. with Ignorance of the fact that the United W Btates has a conscience. We are, he said, a commercial nation. Our people are trained to all refinements of business obligations and all the reciprocal relations of contracts. Much as we want the canal, we never could have taken It by becoming a partner in this highway robbery Df the property of the citizens of France. Mr. rpevr controverted the argument that the potijtion of the United States in recognizing the Republic of Panama was a reversal of the na tional position on Eecestlon. After reviewing diplomatic history in the rec- Dgnition of new countries. Mr. Depew said No State ever became independent so completely, to righteously, or so timely as Panama. The hour truck for her when the world was watch- Ing toe clock. No President ever did a more timely or mere patriotic act than did President Roosevelt In his recognition and defense of the Republic cf Panama. Mr. Derew ridiculed as lurid the contention that the President had made war on Colombia- He declared that in his dependence on the De mocracy of the United States, President Mar roguin forgot that party was not in power in ny branch of the government of this country, nd that two of the Southern States had already Instructed tht-ir Senators to vote for the canal treaty, and others were likely to follow their trarr Mr Newlands, of Nevada, spoke in criticism of the President's policy. He also as tented to the proposition that the United State bad a grievance against Colombia 02 account of the rejection of the Hay-Herran treaty. But he contended that the action of the United Btates In preventing the landing of Colombian troops in Panama was an intervention that mounted to a declaration of war. He engaged In a controversy with Mr. Fpooner as to the guarantee of the right of transit. He said he was willing to admit that the spirit of the treaty nf 1846 calls for the building of the canal, but even with that construction Colombia's refusal to allow the building of the canal would not have been cause tor war or for the landing of American troops in Panama. He also com plained that the President had prematurely recognized Panama. The established methods of fliplcmacy were ignored, and immediate and prompt trmtd intervention and a display of force were made, without complying with the formal procedure required by international law. Had these, outrages been committed, Mr. Newlands added, by the Executive en a great power like England or Russia or Germany, Con gress would promptly disavow them and shall the impotence of Colombia disqualify her from receiving satisfaction for injury inflicted on her Kr the unauthorized and unconstitutional action of this country's Chief Executive Mr. Spooner congratulated Mr. Newlaads on whit he called an espousal of the doctrine of in ternational eminent domain. A SERVICE PENSION BILL To Be Introduced in Congress with President's Approval. Washington. Jan. 14. A service pension bill will be introduced in the Senate to-morrow by Mr. Dolliver, of lowa, and In the House by Mr. Calderhead, of Kansas, when the House meets again on Monday. The bill is backed by the Grand Army of the Republic and if enacted into law will give a pension of 12 a month to every soldier who served ninety days in the Union Army in the Civil War, who was honor ably discharged therefrom, and who has attained the age of sixty-two years. A like pension will be given to tbe widows of such soldiers in all casts whre the marriage took place before June 27, 1890. The Introduction of the bill Is the result of the meeting In Washington of the committee on pensions of the Grand Army. The committee had an extended conference with the President to-day, and he assured them of his entire sym pathy in their undertaking. They also talked with Pension Commissioner Ware about their work. The bill, it is explained, is not designed to in terfere with existing pension legislation and It provide in terms that no soldier or widow re ceiving a pension under Us provisions shall be entitled to a pension under any other law. TWO SCIENTISTS DEAD. Mother arid Daughter, of Laconia, N. 11. , Wouldn't Have Doctor. BT TKIECBi-PH TO TUB TBIBUXE.J Laconla, X. H., Jan. 14. Mrs. Mary McLosky, seventy-three years old, nnd her daughter Alice, thirty-three years old, both residents of this city, are dead from pneumonia, and the certificate 6igned by Dr. George H. Saltmarsh. local physi cian, called into the case, gives as the cause of death lack of care and proper treatment. Mrs. McLosky died on January 0, after having refused to accept the cervices of a physician. Miss McLosky, who was ill with the same mal ady at the death of the mother, died on January 12 In the same circumstances. Last Monday the daughter was attended by a Christian Science healer from Boston, who administered treat ment consistent with the faith to restore the young woman to normal heaith. The Boston healer gave assurance that her condition was much improved so much so that he urged her removal to Boston, where she would be more in touch with Christian Science healers and him self in particular. So much assurance was attached to the healer's statements that friends, against their own desires and satisfied that tbe unfortunate woman was even then at death's door, assisted her to take a train for Boston. A few hours later 6he reached her destination. Chariestown, Mass., the home of a sister-in-law. Mrs. William B. McLosky, where death came three hours after ber arrival. Miss McbMfcy as well as the mother had been 6trong beiievers in Christian Science for three years, and were both charter members and chief organizers of the Laeonia Christian Bcience So ciety, instituted here early last epringf. Mis. McLosky bad lived here twenty-five years, be ing wne of. the city's most esteemed residents, and like the daughter, was popular. Both formed a wide circle of friends and acquaint ances outside of vaiious social and religious or ganizations to which they were prominently identified for many years. At the time of her illness, despite the entreaty of relatives and iriend, Mrs. McLosky refused medical attendance, and the same was true of the daughter, the latter being ewn more strenuously opposed to receiving assistance from a physician. The developments in the case have stirred public sentiment here to a high pitch as nothing in the. line of such unusual happenings in the Winnipesaiikee Valley has produced such niental tension before for many years. The funeral of Miss Mclysky took place at Park Street Free Will Baptist Church this afternoon. So far as observation extended not a single member of the Christian Science faith was among the audience which packed the auditorium to the doors. The body was deposited beside that of the mother, in the family tomb at Bayslde Cemetery. OEE WORTH 250, A TON. Found in Two-Inch Streaks in a Cripple Creek Mine. BI TELEnAI-H TO TUC TIMBCNE. The Appointment of Ex-Commissioner Hynes the Last Straw. Charles T. Murphy returned from Washington yesterday at 4 p. m., but he did not go to Tam many Hall, where about fifty politicians were wait ing to ask him several pointed Questions about Mayor McClellan's appointments. Mr. Murphy made the trip from Washlntfton with Norman E. Mack, and after reaching his home, in Stuyvesaut Square, denied himself to all callers. The Mayor's latest offence, in the opinion of Tammany men, was committed yesterday, when he announced the appointment of Thomas W. Hynes, Commissioner of Correction under the Low admin istration, to be New-York City's commissioner to the St. Louis Exposition. Where does Hynes come in How long has Hynes belonged to the organiza tion Who stands for Hynes These were some of the questions asked yester day at Tammany Hall, and again last night at the Anawanda Club, whose members are still waiting fur patronage. The barren results of the old fash ioned political game of promising things and not delivering the goods is causing many heartburn ings in Tammany Hall. SHOT HIS SWEETHEART. Followed Quarrel with Girl's Mother Arrest and Confession. South Norwalk, Conn., Jan. 14. William Car penter, twenty-one years old. shot and seriously wounded his sweetheart. Miss Margaret Nevils, to-night. Carpenter fired at the girl three times, and each shot took effect. Miss Nevils was car ried to the South Norwalk Hospital, and the physicians, after an examination, said that the girl's condition was critical. Carpenter at tempted to escape after the shooting, but was caught by the police. At Police Headquarters he confessed to Chief Vollmer. but said that the shooting was not premeditated. Carpenter, whose home Is in Stamford, has been calling on Miss Nevils for some time. To night be had an argument with the girl's mother. When he left the house Miss Nevlls accompanied him to the street, where, accord- Ing to his own story, he renewed the argument with the girl, who had been upholding her mother. The couple were walking near the Nevlla home, when Carpenter suddenly drew a revolver from his pocket and tired three shots in rapid succession at the girl. One bullet en tered one of the girl's lungs, another struck her in the chin and the third made a glancing wound on the cheek. The first bullet was the most serious of the three, and at the hospital it was feared that it had penetrated the abdominal wall and entered the stomach. Carpenter, after firing the shots, turned and ran across a vacant lot and out onto the street. He had Just started down the street, when he ran into the arms of a policeman, who had heard the shots and who was hurrying to investigate the cause. The policeman took Carpenter to the hospital to which Miss Nevils had been re now .1. The young woman identified Carpenter as the m.-in who fired the shots. Carpenter was then takn to the police station, where he broke town and cried violently. He admitted the jhootiig, but said that in th heat of an argu ment with the girl he lost his head and fired the shots without realizing what he was doing. .9. P. A. XOW DEBT FREE. First Time in Its History Build ing Mortgage Paid. President Haines. in his annual report for tho Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Ani mals, says that all encumbrances on the Madl ron-ave building have been removed, and that for the first time In its history the society Is entirely free from debt. The report ay The year 1903 has benn a time of serious an3 severe trial to nearly all charitable associations in the city of New- fork. It is reported on ex cellent authority that the managers of every hospital in the city are confronted with a de ficit of thousands of dollars In their receipts as compare with their necessary expenditures. In some cases the amount is so great aa to cause serious embarrassment, and tho total, so far as reported, reacboa the large sum of nearly half a million of dollars. According to the best in formation I have been able to obtain, a similar shrinkage of income has been experienced In nearly. If not quite, all other charitable institu tions. We have not only been enabled to pay every dollar of the year's expenses, but aiso to extinguish the last mortgage with which the headquarters of tbe society were burdened. The death of Frederic Reno Ceudert. who waa actively connected with the society, is referred to as causing a serious loss to the organization. The various special Instances where the so ciety has Interfered In behalf of abused ani mals during the last year are referred to. A long distance race from Chadron to Chicago was practically broken up, says Mr. Haines, through the posting of warnings along the proposed route. Only nine entries were finally made, and no hard riding was done. Another, planned to take place between Omaha and Dead wood, Mr. Haines states, was prevented altogether. Th bullfight plannefl for the Alabama State Fair, the proposed cocking main near Louisville, Ky., and a simUar affair to have taken place near Birmingham, Ala., are mentioned as having been prevented by the society. Mr. Haines also takes to the organization the credit for pre venting a cat-mice-catching tournament at Stamford, Coun. The only change in the personnel of the board of munagera is the appointment of Frederic R. Coudert, Jr., to fill the vacancy caused by his father's death. George Herman, who was at one time chief Inspector of the constabulary and who, in company with C. J. Johnson, an other constabulary officer, robbed the govern ment and then started upon a piratical cruise on the vessel they stole, has just escaped from prison at Cebu. He is still at large. Herman was captured off Bayauan by one of the parties In search of him. Johnson, whose body was found in their abandoned boat, had been shot the day before by the constables in a fight in which Herman shot and killed four men. TO KEEP OUT SILVER COINS. STAGE FOLK STRANDED. Six Thousand Out of Work in Chicago. TBT TELBHSAPII TO THE TEIBfXE. Chicago. Jan. .TO. -Six thousand stage folk are stranded here, it is estimated by agents. With the number being increased daily through the cloning of theatre and attractions in neighbor ing cities and States, this city, because of the Iroquois fire and Its results, is now the centre of the greatest pnnlc that has overtaken the amusement business In its history In America. Showing a serenity puzzling to the public and even to those in close touch with the theatrical profession, managers, agents, actors, actresses, chorus girls, stage mechanics, bill posters and members of other crafts identified with the mimic world are awaiting want. Yet they spurn ofTcrs of engagements at panic salaries. and murmur unpleusant criticism about some of the alleged benefits planned In the name of the profession. THE BANCROFT IX ACTION San Bias Indians Attempt to Capt ure Gunboat. Colon. Jan. 29 The I'nited States gunboat Bancwrft arrived hen to-day from the San Bias roast. She reports the attitude of the San Bias Indians at Caledoria Bay to be not only unfriendly, but decidedly aggressive. Last Tuesday men from one of the Bancroft's boats Insisted upon buying a few cocoanuts from th Indians, and paid more than full value for them. Toward 11 o'clock that night, when it was dark, twenty canoes were seen approaching the Ban croft. The gunboat turned her searchlight on the caaees, and it showed that each boat car ried as n'.iiny Indians as i-ouU possibly crowd in. probaMy two hundred in all. All the men were armed with bows and arrows, guns of quaint old pattern and other weapons. Their fans were besmeared with paint. There is no doubt that their Intentions were hostile. They hoped to reach and surprise the ship. The commander of the Bancroft ordered th Kunboat cleared for action, and her guns were loaded and trimmed ready for use. A quick firing Colt gun was placed near the gangway, and orders were given to the gunners of this piece to keep up a ceaseless fire all around the canoes. As soon as the- Tndians heard this rain of bul lets they immediately began retreating toward the shore. The gunners werr ordered not to fire, at the Indians, so the briilet3 cut the air and churned up the water around them. Tho question of making theatres In this city safe and preventing a disaster In New-York like that at the Iroquots Theatre In Chicago was considered yesterday at a conference be tween Mayor UcClellan, Firs Commissioner Hares. Police Commissioner McAdoo, Health Commissioner Darlington, Borough President Ahearn and Theodore Connoly. representing Corporation Counsel Delany. Th Mayor called the conference In his office at the request of Mr. Hayes, and after It was over the Mayor paid he had requested both th Firs Commissioner and the Health Commissioner to hay examina tions made of all the theatres in the five bor oughs of the city. He also had requested the presidents of the boroughs to have their super intendents of buildings make reports about the theatres and other places of amusement In th several boroughs, regarding the manner In which such buildings comply or fail to comply with the building laws. The 'inspection of the theatres by order of Fire oCmcnfMi r r Hayes is .lradly partly completed, and the reports of that inspection will deal chiefly with asbestos curtains, exits and heating and lighting ierent. The Mayor will receive the reports In a day or two. Health Commissioner Darlington report will deal with the sanitary conditions at the theatres, including th means of ventilation. It may be several days before the sanitary of ficials can complete such an investigation. When the reports are received, if it is found that a theatre Is unsafe by reason of failure to comply with the lire, sanitary and building regulations, the Mayor may take steps to close it until the place is made safe. When 1 receive the reports, Mayor McClellan caM yesterday, I shall take such action as will prevent any violation of the law at the theatres In the future, and stop any that is discovered. I have taken the action to-day because of the Justifiable public sentiment which has been aroused by the Chicago fire. Will you close any theatre if its manager shows a disposition to delay such alterations as may be found necessary was asked. NOT TO CONSIDER MANAGERS. We shall override any each disposition, th Mayor said. The convenience of th theatre managers Is not to be considered when it Is a question of life or death for the public. Borough President Ahearn pent for Mr. Thompson. the Superintendent of Buildings, and ordered him to let everything else wait upon an inspection of the theatre buildings In Manhat tan. He told Mr. Thompson to have th reports on the theatres ready at the earliest possible minute. Fire Commissioner Hayes said In the after noon that be had received a special report from Foreman Lenihan regarding the asbestos cur tains in theatres in Manhattan. Th report says that all the theatres have asbestos curtains which appear to be fireproof and in good work ing order except the Orpheus Music Hall, at No. 125 Bast One-hundredf-and-twenty-liflh-st tha Circle Theatre, at Broadway and Slxtleth-st.. and Huber's Museum, at No. 10j East Four teenth-st. The Commissioner Bald he had not taken any st3p to dose those places of amuse ment whl-h had do asbestos curtains for the stage, as he did not know that he had the power to take such action, but he was willing to let the public know of the lack of safety at those places. The Mayor yesterday asked Police Commis sioner llcAdoo to have two additional police men stationed in es h theatre during each per formance. One of the policemen is to stay in the balcony and the Other In the gallery, and they will expected to see that there is no blocking of th stairways or aisles or over crowding of the lobbies. In case of disturb ances from any cause, the police would be ex pected to Bid hi preventing panics. WORLD MARKETS AND POLITICS. Membership in Coisres3 Is Increasing In both honor and importance. Circumstances have forced us to depart from the oldtime rule sepa rating us from the affairs of the rest of the world, and many of the policies we are adopting now not only affect other people than our own, but look far ahead Into the future, one accord our public men are directing thei atten tions to the great problem of securing new mar kets for American made good. The Americas policy is not one of conquest or of paramount political Influence, It does not ask special con sideration. It asks no more than an equal ritrht for th.- American people to trade In the world's markets, and It opposes the policy of any nation which, going outside of its own territory, under takes to set up metes and bounds within which Its p -ople can trade. our entrance Into world politics. if so larpe an expression be descriptive, has been eyed by the other nations In a spirit of hearty friend ship They have the assurance of our physical situation that It can have no ulterior purpose. but it brings to us as members of Congress new questions and new responsibilities, and I take It to be a great privilege to be a member of the House or the Senate at this time in our country's development The necessity of new markets and better commercial facilities was felt by the people long before it appeared In government policies. The construction of an Isthmian canal transcends In importance any other act of legislation or diplomacy to which the government can commit itself, and the peo ple will look impatiently, In my opinion, at any individual OT political party that seeks to em barrass this work with partisan outcries. If this session of Congress accomplishes nothing els- than to render possible the Immediate con struction of the canal across the isthmus, it will have done enough to entitle it to a hisch place in the list of useful and memorable ses sions. . Th trial of Senator Dietrich for allege bribery, in connection with a post fflce appointment at Hastings, Neb., ciune to an abrupt end to-day when the United States Clr ult Court, Judge Van Devanter presiding, de cided that Mr Dietrich was not a Senator at the time the alleged acts occurred. The opinion iva a Jong one. and is said to establish a precedent. The effect of the decision Is that a man Is not an actual member of Congress from the time of hit lection until he takes the oath at the bar of the bouse to which he is elected, and that he Is not amenable to the law as a member of Con gress and officer of the United States In that in terval. Diirlct Attorney Summers entered a nolle roejul in the other cases against the Senator nd Postmaster Jacob Fisher, of Hastings, Neb.. with the statement that the construction placed on the law by the court precluded further pro ceedings against either Senator Dietrich or Mr. r lLer. both of whom were discharged. On account of a statement made to the press torn time ago on behalf of Senator Dietrich, to she effect that he did not wish to take advan tage of any technicality, but v.anted the case tried on Its merits. In order that he might be fully vindicated. Genera Cowln, Senator Diet rich's chief counsel, to-day gave out a state ment of his reasons for demurring to the in dictment. In effect it was that, as the court Itself would insist on an adjudication of the question whether Mr. Dietrich were a United Ptatei Senator during the period covered by the alleged unlawful acts. General Cowln decided that the demurrer should be Interposed before the taking of testimony should begin. He ex plained that otherwise the court, at the close of the case for the prosecution, would raise the point In question, which would preclude the de fence from presenting any evidence in refuta tion of the testimony introduced by the prosecu tion. V.'hen General Cowln'a statement was shown to District Attorney Summers he said The answer to that statement Is this Official ly this office has nothing to pay the court has settled the matter. If Senator Dietrich desired to secure a vindication through a trial of the case on its merits, he had an opportunity to do -o by not raising the technical point of whether or not h was a member of Congress from the time of his election to his taking the oath of office. If the House of Refuge, on Randall's Island, reveals any possible weak point ln the armor of Its fire precautions and facilities, the weakness apparently lies not so much in the safeguards to prelect its Inmates as to protect the officers and matrons themselves. In the officers' and matrons' quarters, which lie to the extreme right and left of the main building, the complete absence of fire escapes is not atoned for by the presence of only one exit in each case. This exit, however, could scarcely be better than It is one of the s'.ate and iron corridors that are a feature of the Refuge. That no possible precaution shall be neglected, how ever. Superintendent Omar V. Page yesterday, ln view of the Chicago theatre holocaust, wrote the Department of Charities recommending the erection of two fire escape. one attached to the male officers' quarters and another to the ma trons' quarters, asking in the meanwhile for iroo staples and one-Inch rope in case of an emer gency at these points. An Investigation of the entire fire arrange ments on Randall's Island by a Tribune re porter yesterday went to show that resources in care of fire which at the Island hospital, in fants' hoypital end schools under Superintend ent Mrs. M. C. Dunphy were unexceptionable, reached a high standard ln the House of Ref uge, under Superintendent Gage. Unlike the western division of Ward's Island. the condition of arnica was told In yesterday's Tribute, both divisions of Randall's have two firemen specially detailed, good and abundant hse, a modern fire engine periodically tested and inspected, and other facilities and protec tions. By the Superintendent of tha House of Ref vge. however, the engine house is regarded as a rather secondary portion of his fire fighting apparatus, for the especially adapted fire pre cautions and contrivances In the Refuge Include four water tanks, each containing a uniform quantity of water some l. gallons which newer varies, however much may be withdrawn. A well trained volunteer fire brigade, some fifty strong two trebly fireproof slate and Iron stair nays In each of tho fourteen boys' and girls' dormitories, and stand plpe and hose ln every dormitory connected with the tanks, make pos sible an almost instantaneous flushing of any portion of the Refuge. In both divisions the general local fire signal Is a long ear-splitting blast, followed by three short ones from a upecially constructed siren, called the Great Whistle. whose sound, it is asserted, on a clear day can he heard for a distance of thirty miles. The fifty-two boys of the First Division ln the House of Refuse, who are quartered on the east side of the first hall. are the institution's fire brigade, commanded by the military instructor. .They take part ln a practical fire drill at least or.cc a week. A periodic fire alarm test is also given to the en tire body of the Inmates. The fact that ln each dormitory, throughout the night, an officer is stationed on a dais also tends to lessen the chinee of any possible surprise by fire in this direction. Seeks the Co-operation of Theatrical Men in Safeguarding Public. There will be a continuous performance in the Mayor's office at the City Hall to-day, begin ning at 9 a. m.. at which the theatre managers of Manhattan wilJ take turns in heart to heart talks with Mayor McClellan. Announcement of the programme for to-day vias made late yesterday afternoon by the Mayor, after he had held an hour's conference with Corporation Couns-1 Delany, Fire Commissioner Hayes, Health Commissioner Darlington. President Ahearn of Manhatan Borough and Mr. Thomp son, the superintendent of buildings for Man hattan. The purpose of the conference which I have held, the Mayor said, has been to produce harmonious action among the departments hav ing relations with the theatres, because the reg ulations as to the theatres divide the responsi bility. The conferences have shown that all the departments concerned are glad to co-operate in united action to make the theatres of the city safe. There have been inspections going on day by day, and the reports of such inspections have been before us. As a result of the conferences, I have asked all the theatre managers in Manhattan to come here and see me to-morrow and talk over with me plans for making theatres safe. I want them to co-operate with me in carrying out recom mendations which are to be formulated by a commute composed of representatives of the Fire Df-partment, the Health Department and the Department of Buildings. This committed will get together immediately and report general reconui.endailons as to changes in the theatres, and these recommendations will be given to the managers for their sruidance. The purpose we have ln view Is to safeguard the public and allay apprehension at the theatres. For that reason we believe the man agers vi ill co-operate with us. The recommenda tions of the committee will be of a character to apply to all theatres. They may be formulated to-night or to-morrow, and I expect them to be ready certainly by Monday morning. Are you to have all the theatre managers here together was asked. Oh. no, said the Mayor. They will come before me one at a time, beginning at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning. The conditions at the va rious theatres differ, and each theatre manager will be asked to co-operate In making changes according to condition. Suppose some of the managers do not want to co-operate in carrying out the recommenda tions We shall put. the recommendations Into ef fect. said the Mayor, sharply, but there is a question whether we can put them into effect at once, or slowly. We want the co-operation of the managers in order hat the recommendations can be earned out at once. Probably there will be no necessity for closing any theatres. Henry S. Thompson. Ratification of Panama Treaty Not Likely To Be Delayed Long. fFBOM THE TRIBUTE BUREAC.I Washington. Jan. 15. 1t Is hoped that the consideration of the Panama Canal treaty by the Foreign Relations Committee will be com pleted in a few days, after which it will be taken up in the Senate. Senator Gorman to day proposed amendments to the set of resolu tions offered by him which render them. In the opinion of leading Republicans, entirely in nocuous, so that they are likely to be adopted at an early date. This change is regarded as Inrgely in the nature of a retreat on the part of the Senator from Maryland, who probably has finally come to appreciate how entirely un tenable is his opposition to the Panama treaty. Once the treaty is reported to the Senate the rublic debate will cease. Almost continuous executive sessions will be held, and final ratifi cation is not likely to be seriously delayed. The debate of the last week is re'gaxded as having cleared the atmosphere and prepared the way for ratification, and once more the prospect of a comparatively early adjournment Is being dis cussed. PAX AM A W THE SENATE. Spooner and Tillman Have Another Lively Colloquy. Washington. Jan. 15. After the passage of a number of minor measures to-day, tna Gorman Panama resolution wap laid before the Senate. Mr. Gorman offered a number of amendments, striking out the word Intervention wherever it appears, thus modifying the resolution so as to make it an inquiry of the President concerning the use of American military forces in the Isthmus of Pan ama. Mr. Cullom. in view of the amendments, withdrew his motion to refer the resolution to the Committee on Foreign Relations, and said he was willing to have a vote on it. Mr. Lodge, however, asked to have the resolu tion, as amended, printed, and lie over for an other day. and that order was made. Mr. Teller then spoke on the Panama question, sayiug he believed it should be treated from a non partisaa point of view. H thought, however, that whenever the President transcended his duty the fact should be pointed out. In the present instance he did not doubt the good intentions of tha Presi dent, but he distrusted of his wisdom in what he had done. His objection was not. he said, based on any fear of war with Colombia, because Co lombia had shown that she was too wise to enter into a conflict of arms with the United States. He had no complaint to make against Panama, for he thought the people of that country had the right to revolt. Indeed, he thought if he had lived in Panama he would have been a rebel himself. Thla right of the Panamans did not, however, alter the duty of the United States to remain neutral. He asserted that a new State coming into existence by secession should be recognised only when It had established its capacity to maintain its indepen dence. There should be no interference so long as there was a likelihood of the success of the parent State. This rule. Mr. Teller dtclared, had not been ni in Panama. Mr. Platt. of Connecticut, asked whether under any circumstances the United States had a right to protect transit across the Isthmus, but Mr. Teller declared that the question was academic and said he would not argue the case on that general ground. He was willing to discuss the right to interfere as the President had done, and was ready to contend that his interference was in con travention of international law. When Mr. Teller referred to Mr. Tman's char acterization of the situation on the isthmus, the latter interrupted to say that he had been mis understood and desired to explain. He meant to say that it would have been preferable for the United States to tell Colombia to get on the isth mus entirely than for us to pursue there the methods of the sneak thief and maintain the atti tude of a bully. In response to a Suggestion made by Mr. Teller, Mr. Spooncr interrupted to say that by tfte treaty of 1546 Colombia was bound to maintain the per petual right of the United States to passage across the isthmus and he argued that that right re mains, even though Colombia dors not etand be hind it. Mr. Teller admitted that any right the United States had under Colombia she still had under Panama, if Panama was an established power. He then asked tor an opinion from Mr. Spooner con cerning the new theory Jof International eminent domain. and tho latter replied that he had not yet been able to jdvo his assent to that doctrine, which, as he understood it, meant that when a weak nation had what .1 strong nation needed the latter mieht take it ly means of arms if neces sary. Yet it must be remembered that right of way of one landowner over lamd owned by another person Is a. right recognized by the world. If. he eaid. there is a doctrine of the private way of necessity, are we to pay that there is not an inter national way of necessity where the interest of the world is concerned - There were interruptions at this point, causing Mr. Tillman to remark that It taken a gr3t many doctors to bring about the birth of this baby. I'll try to take care of my own baby, respond ed Mr. Spooner. and when I can't do that I will ask some member of my own family to do so. The colloquy caused a general outburst of laugh ter. After it had FUbsided Mr. Spooner continued his statement, saying he was willing to confess that he had not reached a conclusion In his own mind. I am not willing to concede the rifrhr of International eminent domain, but I can't find it in my heart to deny it. h paid. Mr. Teller look issue with the President's dec laration that the course pursued in Panama had teen in the interest of ''collective civilization. That, he said, was a dangerous doctrine, and was Just Fueh a doctrine as Russia might apDeal to if Fhe should attempt to crush Japan. The doctrine was not Americar. It was contrary to all the best traditions of this country. It was the doctrine that might makes right. He discussed the government of Panama, declaring it to be unrepublican 'n form, and was interrupted by Mr. Spooner. who said that it had been a mooted question as to whether there is a republican form of government in Colorado. If. responded Mr. Teller, there is not a re publican form of government in Colorado, there is a Republican administration there. When Mr. Teller ceased speaking, the Senate passed a large number of private pension bills and adjourned until Monday. ORGANIZING IN PANAMA. Constitutional Convention Meets Good Feeling Shown. Panama. Jan. 15. Members of the Junta and several consular representatives were present to-day at the first session of the Constitutional Convention, which was also attended by a great crowd of, people. Dr. Pablo Arosemena, temporary president of the convention, delivered the opening address, which was repeatedly interrupted by applause. Among other things, he said The republic will live less by Its material power than by the virtues it will practice. In dependence must be maintained and the republic must adopt without reserve that policy of probity which is born of justice and knowledge. Dr. Arosemena reviewed the favorable au spices under which the republic had been born, and said Its security is protected by a powerful peo ple in whose veins runs the rich blood of those Puritans who shook off the torment of re ligious intolerance and the opprobrium of politi cal despotism. Dr. Arosemena concluded by recommending that in the exercise of their duties the members of the convention should keep their country in their hearts and minds. Dr. Eusebia Morales delivered the Junta's menage to the convention, after which the ministers left the meeting. The B TenttOW appointed Aristicies Arjona. Juan Batista Amador and Manuel C. Jurado a committee to draw up un answer to the Junta's mcraag . l-.ixsentatlve Burgos proposed that ths convention should fend patriotic Balute to the Junta for its distinguished services to the country. This was unanimously approved, thus Indicating the cardinal relations which exist be tween the legislative and executive jjowers. GUATEMALA RECOGNIZES PANAMA. Washington. Jar.. BY CONGRESS DISTRICTS HERE. William Barnes, Jr.. Says Invariable Custom Will Be Followed Cdell Says Nothing. BT TKLEGRArU TO THE TRIBUNE. Albany. Jan. 15. William Barnes. Jr.. was asked to-night if he would comment on The Tribune's Washington dispatch concerning the rumored double dealing as to President Roosevelt disclosed in the delay in the issuance of the call for the national convention. Mr. Barnes declared that, beyond having heard the rumor circulating in the lact week, he knew nothing of the matter. As far aa thla State Is concerned, said he, the nomination of delegates will follow the in variable custom and be by Congress districts. Baron Hayashi's Comment on the Emperors Statement. Ijondon. Jan. 15. Baron Hayashl. the Japan ese Minister here, commenting to-nlsht on the dispatch from St. Petersburg quoting the peace ful statement made by the Czar to members of tho diplomatic corps yesterday, at the New Tear's reception, said I have read wtth pleasure the statement at tnhufl to the Czar. If these are his majesty's views there will be no war. The question rests with him. Japan ha nothing further to say. The minister added that he had received a dis p4ftch' from Toklo denying- the staterafent that Japan was trying to induce Corea to recognize a Japanese protectorate. It Is practically certain that any declaration of war will not emiinate from Russia, said Baron Hayashi in an interview earlier in the day. The minister was not very hopeful of the result of the latest Japanese note, but he spe cifically denied that Japan's reply suggests the neutralization of a part of Manchuria as well as a part of Corea, or that mention ia made of the right to break off negotiations. He added Cur conditions are practically summed up In the concluding portion of the Stats Depart ment's announcement regarding the Cblno-Amer ican treaty. For these principles, to which Secretary Hay says the United States is irrev ocably committed, we are 'willing to go to war unless Russia will consent to give us a definite pledge that she, too, adheres to the open door and Chinese sovereignty In Manchuria. HOPES HIGHER IN RUSSIA, Japan's Reply Seems Likely to Lead to More Conferences. St. Petersburg, Jan. 15. The Japanese Min ister, M. Kurino, to-day delivered the Japanese reply to the Foreign Office here. The reply ia now under consideration. The Foreign Office says that the present stage of the negotiations is In some respects in ad vance on previous 6toges. and that the two governments have approached an understanding on some points, but not on others. There was hopefulness to-day in many quar tern where pessimism formerly prevailed. Con servative opinion holds that, while the prospect of peace is better than ever, the end cannot be predicted with certainty, particularly the man ner in which a settlement can be obtained. Congressman John Sharp Williams tells of a mar. in Mississippi who is a hypochondriac of the first order. This individual's failing is a source of never ending amusement to his fellow townsmen. It was of this man that some one humorously remarked, in answer to a question, as to how the sick man was getting on, that he complained that he was feeling somewhat better. Mr. Williams says that the hypochondriac was one day telling a friend of his efforts to regain his old time health. He ran over the list of tors whom, he had consulted. I desire and intend to do all in my power to maintain peace In the Far East. These were the words which the Czar spoke to the members of the diplomatic corps at the yew Year's reception, hold in the Winter Palace ,t noon to-day. The Czar made a leisurely round' of the great arlJite hall, with its beautiful colonnades. In -hich the representatives of the various coun tries had assembled. He chatted freely with all and at considerable length with, several of the diplomats. Keen curiosity was exhibited by every one in the room when his majesty approached Mr. Kurtno, the Japanese Minister to Russia. The conversation between the Cxar and the minister was cordial and extended. His majesty em phasized the high value which he placed on the good and neighborly relations between Japan nd Russia, not only now, but In the future, and expressed his unshaken hope that a mutually tlsfactory settlement of the difficulties be tween the two countries would ' be arrange. IJlnister Kurino left the reception profoundly Impressed wlti hlrs majesty's words. Mr. Kurino, the Japanese Minister, informed the Associated Press correspondent that the Japanese reply had been handed to Baron de Rose., the Russian Minister at Tokio, and that he himself would present Count Lamsdorff, the Russian Foreign Minister, with a duplicate copy. The minister said he wm not authorized to state the terms of the reply, but he admitted that It Insured the continuance of negotiations con cerning the Far East so far as Japan was con cerned. Tke ship were recently purchased from the Arirentlne government, for whom they wer built at Gnoa. REJECTS ICE TRUST BIDS PRICE FOR CITY DOUBLED. Health Commissioner Darlington to Advertise Anew for Supply. The Ice Trust is doing, or trying to do, busi nesa at the old stand. It has doubled the price of Hb commodity In its bids to supply the Health Department with Jco thnt last year cost 27,. Commissioner Darlington of the Health Board yesterday decided to reject the trust's bid and readvertise for proposals. The American Ice Company last year fur nished the department now under my Jurisdic tion with Ice at 13 cents a hundred pounds, Fa Id Dr. Darlington. The b-ids opened to-day seem to be all from one concern, and the price Is raised from 13 to '2ft cents a hundred pounds. This Is so outrageous that I will not stand it. I have decided to reject the bids and try again. Tammany Hall is supposed to have come back to power as a protest against the so-called predatory trusts. The Ice Trust seems to have chosen the advent of Democracy's return to power as a fitting chance to double the price of Us commodity. I don't believe we shall be com pelled to buy ice from the trust at such an ap parently excessive price. Commissioner Darlington had a conference with Controller CJrout yesterday and it Is un derstood that thq Controller advised him with reference to tactics in fighting the Ice Trus'.. The American Ice Company gained notoriety on account of its promotion by the bad-rs of Tammany Hall in litol. Mayor Van Wyck and John F. Carroll were large stockholders In the company at that time and the company enjoyed water front privileges which enabled it to mo nopolize the ice business of the city. More recently an investigation committee of the stockholders, after an examination of the ice company's affaire, criticised pome Of its business methods. James Cad mus, eleven years old, is in the custody of the Erie Railroad officials on the charge of having attempted to wreck a fast expiess on the New- York and Greenwood Lake Railway at Soho by placing a large bowlder on the tracks. The fact that a serious wreck was averted was due to the arrival of James Frazer, who, knowing that it was time for a fast express, ran to the cne and rolled the bowlder down an embankment. He then reported the fact to the authorities and. aided by the company's detective, made the arrest. Chicago, Jan. 14 Fifteen churches wre closed to-day for violationa of the building ordinances, and Building Commissioner Williams placed them all under police guard until alterations are made. The three largest are the First Meth odist Church, Jewish Temple Anshe Kanmani Israel and the Catholic Church of the Nativity of Our Lord. In addition to closing the churches, policemen were sent to guard a number of lodging houses, nnd the building ir. which a commercial college is situated was closed. This building must be remodelled extensively before it can be re opened, and the college In the mean time will seek other quarters. Arrangements were made to-day ly Mayor Harrison and the proprietors of the Iroquols Theatre by which the building is to be Sjsed to test automatic sprinklers, fire extinguishers and kindred appliances before It Is reconstructed. Ther wil be no large fire permitted In the buldl.ig. only sufficient heat being provided to test the fusible caps on sprinklers. Tests of theatrical curtains will also be made, and the eff -ler.cy of all appliances required by the city fire ordlinncp.i will be demonstrate'. From action taken to-night by the City Coun cil It Is evident that the theatres here will not be able to reopen for smr.e time. The meeting of the Council was to consider the revision of the buildln ordinances, and It was generally expected that th- proposed amendments would be considered and adopted, s-o that the proprie tors of the theatres would know what would be demanded of them and would be able to begin their alterations at once. Hut thre has been much criticism of the proposed changes In the ordinances, and when the measure was called up to-night Alderman Mayor moved thai con sideration be deferred. The motion was passed, and all consideration of the new ordinance was postponed until the Council is ready WAXT POPE'S HELP. GEORGE STORM A SUICIDE. FEARED APPENDICITIS, No Other Cause Known IV as Head of Owl Commercial Company. Dread of an operation for appendicitis appears to have been the cause of the suicide yesterday of George Storm, president of the Owl Com mercial Company, at No. IMS East Twenty seventh-st. lie had no known business or family trouble. He Phot himself through the brain. Mr. Storm hart been talking about some busi ness in the oce. Ho bad been in good spirits. but suddenly he jumped from his seat and al most ran Into an inner office. The move did not excite suspicion, but an instant after Mr. Storm had entered the inner office the shot was heard and his partners rushed in Polite Headquarters was Immediately asked by telephone to Bend an ambulance quickly, ii.l a sin hi was soon on the spot. He said death had been almost Instantaneous. The offices of the company were at once closed and the body was sent to an undertaking estab lishment in West Twenty-third-st. Mr. Storm lived at the Hotel Savoy with his wife and two daughters. lit was a member of the Lotos Club, of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and of the American Museum of Natural History. He was a director of the German Exchange Hank. His son. Frederick Storm, is secretary of the Owl Commercial Company, of which Peter Miller is treasurer. Mr. Storm was an undo of George L. Stern, a cigar manu facturer. Thf directors or the Owl Commercial Company were Peter Miller. George Storm. Frederick Storm, Henry Storm. Robert C. Brown. William M. Corry and Marcus Oppen heimer. Mrs. Storm was rome years the Junior of her husband but their married life was especially happy. Mrs. Dugro. wife of Justice Dugro. broke the news to her. She was completely prostrated. Mr. Miller said later Mr. Storm feared a second attack of appendi citis. While travelling in Germany a year ago he had an attack, but was cured for the time by the absorption method. He was told by the physicians that if he had a second attack he would have to have an operation. I believe it was the dread of this operation that caused Mr. Storm to take his lit- About a week ago he be jr.ui . have the pains that he had a year ago. find be brooded over it. Still Mr. Storm was the last man, you would think, to commit such an act. He was strong i. nd nergettc, and had a powerful will. The business was in the best condition possible In f.T-t. last year wn th.- best we have had in ten years. We sold nil the tobacco that had been picked from our Mi plantations. We can attribute his deed only to one of those Sudden turn. of mind that are almost unexplaln able It bad been some hours since he had mentioned the pains. RUMORS OF TREACHERY Long Delay in Issuing Call for Re publican National Convention, FROM the tribune nrr.EAr. Washington. Jan. 14. startling and apt parentry authentic rumor Involving treachery to President Roosevelt. if not to the national com mittee itself, on the part of the executive com mittee of that organization was in circulation at the Capitol to-day. From sources usually regarded as trustworthy came the Information that the reason lor the unprecedented delay In issuing the call for the Republican National Convention was due to an effort on the part of the executive com nittee to find an excuse lor ao altering the call as to preclude the possibility of selecting delegates for the respective Congress districts and to make necessary Instead the election of all delegates at large. The delay in Itself is already the occasion of surprise and annoyance to numerous tate or ganizations, and unless the call Is issued lrr. n'.-fliately serious inconvenience must ensue but the proposition to change the form of the call and defeat the desire of the party that the usual niethod of selecting delegates he pursued will, if carried out. create widespread indignation. Such a proposition is characterized with reser- vation as an attempt to control certain delega tions which would normally cast their votes far the President in the forthcoming convention, ant. If persisted In. must result in war t tap knife. It is known that in Ohio Senator Fcraker wi control certain delegates, provided the selection is by Congress districts, but Their -.election .-s delegates at large might materially alter thi course of events, and a similar situation prevails in other States. It Is not believed by Senators and others whrv are supposed to have a thorough knowledge c the rules of Republican conventions that any Justification for such a course can be found by th executive committee, although there is a. possibility that some resolution conferring 3uch, power on the committee may have been, unwit tingly adopted by the committee, as was tha case with the resolution which confers on th chairman cf the national committee the power to fill any vacancies which may occur. In any event, should the national committee, determine to take the course outlined, It will meet with the strongest opposition. There Is every reason to believe that not only the lead ers, but the rank and file of the party, would resent such an attempt to defeat the popular will, and would seek redress in one form or an other. Postmaster General Payne, vice-chairman oC the National Committee, declared to-day that there could be no truth in the rumor, because he. as vice-chairman, had heard nothing of It. On the other hand, it is maintained that other members of the committee would readily appre-i ciite the delicate position in which they would place Mr. Payne by Informing him of such a plan, and would naturally refrain from taking him Into their confidence while he remained a member of Mr. Roosevelt's Cabinet. Sufficient importance is attached to the rumoil to cause Senator Penrose to withhold the call for the Pennsylvania State Convention, and the call, already prepared, but not sent out. stilt Has on the desk of Major Andrews, secretary of the Republican State Commit MeanwMla Senator Pen rose has ordered a complete search of th proceedings of Republican conventions, and has gone to Philadelphia to-night, presuma bly to consult Senator Quay and other leaders of the party in his State. It is now five weeks since the meeting el th National Committee, and no call for the Na tional Convention has been Issued, although Senator Manna has received numerous messages and letters from party loaders in all parta of the country urging expedition. Postmaster General Payne explains that, al though such delay is entirely unprecedented, tha call hiving been issued within a weak m a' previous occasions, it Is perfectly natural, si Chairman Hanna and Secretary Heath hive been very busy. The Postmaster General fur ther avers that the call i merely a formality and of no vital Importance. Some of the President's most earnest support ers, however, do no take this view of the case. They ay that the course of the Pennsylvania Republicans in calling, as they expect to. ths State Convention in advance of the issue of thi national call, is irregular, and. were there a rival faction in the field, miht lead to the calling ef subsequent convention, the selection of a, ond delegation and a contest which would be decided by the more powerful element In th- National Convention, while the virtue of beingf the more regular would He with the delegation selected pursuant to the national call. No aneh danger M apprehended in Pennsylvania, who.- the part- organization is characterized by com plete harmony, but there are States where su li embarrassing circumstances might arise. Massachusetts will soon follow the example of Pennsylvania and call it State convention with out waiting fo- the national call, and there is believed to be no danger of complications there nevertheless, the delay Is pregnant with the pos sibilities of confusion and contests in the na tional convention. The laws in some States are very explicit re garding the preliminary advertising of a Stata convention. It is customary to give this ad vertising to the weekly papers, and that com pels time enough for several weekly issues.
